d="M55.8 57.2c-1.78 1.31-5.14 1.31-6.9 0L17.58 34h69.54L55.8 57.19zM0 32.42l42.94 32.62c2.64 1.95 6.02 2.93 9.4 2.93s6.78-.98 9.42-2.93L102 34.34V24H0zM92 88.9L73.94 66.16l-8.04 5.95L83.28 94H18.74l18.38-23.12-8.04-5.96L10 88.94V51.36L0 42.9V104h102V44.82l-10 8.46V88.9"></path></svg></span></span></button></div></div></div><button class="button-link u-margin-s-ver button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" id="show-more-btn" data-aa-button="icon-expand"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show more</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button><div class="banner-options u-padding-xs-bottom"><div class="toc-button-wrap u-display-inline-block u-display-none-from-lg u-margin-s-right"><button class="button-link button-link-secondary button-link-icon-left button-link-has-colored-icon" type="button"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 128 128" height="20" class="icon icon-list"><path d="M23 26a9 9 0 0 0-9 9 9 9 0 0 0 9 9 9 9 0 0 0 9-9 9 9 0 0 0-9-9zm23 4v10h68V30zM23 56a9 9 0 0 0-9 9 9 9 0 0 0 9 9 9 9 0 0 0 9-9 9 9 0 0 0-9-9zm23 4v10h68V60zM23 86a9 9 0 0 0-9 9 9 9 0 0 0 9 9 9 9 0 0 0 9-9 9 9 0 0 0-9-9zm23 4v10h68V90z"></path></svg><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Outline</span></span></button></div><button class="button-link AddToMendeley button-link-secondary u-margin-s-right u-display-inline-flex-from-md button-link-icon-left button-link-has-colored-icon" type="button"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 86 128" height="20" class="icon icon-plus"><path d="M48 58V20H38v38H0v10h38v38h10V68h38V58z"></path></svg><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Add to Mendeley</span></span></button><div class="Social u-display-inline-block" id="social"><div class="popover social-popover" id="social-popover"><div id="popover-trigger-social-popover"><button class="button-link button-link-secondary u-margin-s-right button-link-icon-left button-link-has-colored-icon" type="button" aria-expanded="false" aria-haspopup="true"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 114 128" height="20" class="icon icon-share"><path d="M90 112c-6.62 0-12-5.38-12-12s5.38-12 12-12 12 5.38 12 12-5.38 12-12 12zM24 76c-6.62 0-12-5.38-12-12s5.38-12 12-12 12 5.38 12 12-5.38 12-12 12zm66-60c6.62 0 12 5.38 12 12s-5.38 12-12 12-12-5.38-12-12 5.38-12 12-12zm0 62c-6.56 0-12.44 2.9-16.48 7.48L45.1 70.2c.58-1.98.9-4.04.9-6.2s-.32-4.22-.9-6.2l28.42-15.28C77.56 47.1 83.44 50 90 50c12.14 0 22-9.86 22-22S102.14 6 90 6s-22 9.86-22 22c0 1.98.28 3.9.78 5.72L40.14 49.1C36.12 44.76 30.38 42 24 42 11.86 42 2 51.86 2 64s9.86 22 22 22c6.38 0 12.12-2.76 16.14-7.12l28.64 15.38c-.5 1.84-.78 3.76-.78 5.74 0 12.14 9.86 22 22 22s22-9.86 22-22-9.86-22-22-22z"></path></svg><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Share</span></span></button></div></div></div><div class="ExportCitation u-display-inline-block" id="export-citation"><div class="popover export-citation-popover" id="export-citation-popover"><div id="popover-trigger-export-citation-popover"><button class="button-link button-link-secondary button-link-icon-left button-link-has-colored-icon" type="button" aria-expanded="false" aria-haspopup="true"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 104 128" height="20" class="icon icon-cited-by-66"><path d="M2 58.78V106h44V64H12v-5.22C12 40.28 29.08 32 46 32V22C20.1 22 2 37.12 2 58.78zM102 32V22c-25.9 0-44 15.12-44 36.78V106h44V64H68v-5.22C68 40.28 85.08 32 102 32z"></path></svg><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Cite</span></span></button></div></div></div></div></div><div class="ArticleIdentifierLinks u-margin-xs-bottom text-xs" id="article-identifier-links"><a class="anchor doi anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jpowsour.2024.235406" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener" aria-label="Persistent link using digital object identifier" title="Persistent link using digital object identifier"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jpowsour.2024.235406</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a><a class="anchor rights-and-content anchor-primary" href="https://s100.copyright.com/AppDispatchServlet?publisherName=ELS&amp;contentID=S0378775324013582&amp;orderBeanReset=true" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Get rights and content</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></div><div class="LicenseInfo text-xs u-margin-xs-bottom access-type-label-only"><div class="AccessLabel"><span class="access-indicator"></span>Full text access</div></div><section class="ReferencedArticles"></section><section class="ReferencedArticles"></section><div class="PageDivider"></div><div class="Abstracts u-font-serif" id="abstracts"><div class="abstract author-highlights" id="abs0015" lang="en"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Highlights</h2><div id="abssec0015"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="abspara0015"><ul class="list"><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0010">A kinetic study of O3-NaNFMO by Cu doping and Co coating is introduced.</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0015">Effects of Cu doping have been evaluated.</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0020">Mechanism of and Co coating have been studied.</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0025">Improvement of DCR and Energy Efficiency of pouch cells have been evaluated.</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0030">Surface residual alkali of the material is evaluated.</div></span></li></ul></div></div></div><div class="abstract author" id="abs0010" lang="en"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Abstract</h2><div id="abssec0010"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="abspara0010">Layered transition metal oxides (Na<sub>x</sub>TMO<sub>2</sub>, 0 &lt; x&nbsp;≤&nbsp;1) are considered one of the most promising cathodes for Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) due to their high theoretical capacity and operability. However, Na<sub>x</sub>TMO<sub>2</sub> still faces significant challenges, including poor kinetic performance and low energy efficiency. Herein, in order to enhance the kinetics of NaNi<sub>1/3</sub>Fe<sub>1/3</sub>Mn<sub>1/3</sub>O<sub>2</sub> (NaNFMO), topography control and component design were proposed: First, Cu doping (Cu-NaNFMO) was used to expand lattice channels and improve “flat sheet” of layered oxide, which synergistically enhanced transport kinetics of Na<sup>+</sup>. Second, Co coating (NaNFMO@Co) reacted with surface residue to form a fast-ionic conductor Na<sub>x</sub>CoO<sub>2</sub> (0 &lt; x&nbsp;≤&nbsp;1), which inhibited interfacial side reactions and enhanced transport kinetics of Na<sup>+</sup>. Furthermore, the presence of strong Cu-O bonds in Cu-NaNFMO and fast-ionic conductor Na<sub>x</sub>CoO<sub>2</sub> in NaNFMO@Co led to better electrochemical redox performance, the initial charge specific capacity of NaNFMO was increased from 141.5 mAh g⁻<sup>1</sup> to 145.8 mAh g⁻<sup>1</sup> and 144 mAh g⁻<sup>1</sup>, with capacity retention improving by nearly 10&nbsp;% after 100 cycles. Furthermore, NaNFMO@Co improves ICE from 90.56&nbsp;% to 93.57&nbsp;%. With the improved kinetics, the DCR of pouch cells decreased, and the energy efficiency increased from 93.3&nbsp;% to 94&nbsp;% and 95.7&nbsp;%.</div></div></div></div><ul id="issue-navigation" class="issue-navigation u-margin-s-bottom u-bg-grey1"><li class="previous move-left u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-left"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-left" href="/science/article/pii/S0378775324013648"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-left"><path d="M1 61l45-45 7 7-38 38 38 38-7 7z"></path></svg><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Previous <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span></a></li><li class="next move-right u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-right"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-right" href="/science/article/pii/S0378775324013466"><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Next <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-right"><path d="M1 99l38-38L1 23l7-7 45 45-45 45z"></path></svg></a></li></ul><div class="Keywords u-font-serif"><div id="kwrds0010" class="keywords-section"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Keywords</h2><div id="kwrd0010" class="keyword"><span>Sodium-ion battery</span></div><div id="kwrd0015" class="keyword"><span>Cu doping</span></div><div id="kwrd0020" class="keyword"><span>Co coating</span></div><div id="kwrd0025" class="keyword"><span>Improved kinetics</span></div><div id="kwrd0030" class="keyword"><span>Pouch cell</span></div></div></div><div class="Body u-font-serif" id="body"><div><section id="sec1"><h2 id="sectitle0030" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">1. Introduction</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0040">In recent years, the continuous development of energy storage and electric vehicles has led to widespread use of Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) due to their high specific capacity, long cycling performance, and high energy density [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib1" name="bbib1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">1</span></span></a>]. However, the high cost of LIBs is a significant drawback, primarily due to the scarcity and uneven distribution of lithium resources in nature. Additionally, the recycling of lithium sources from spent batteries is challenging and inefficient [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib2" name="bbib2" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[2]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib3" name="bbib3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[3]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib4" name="bbib4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[4]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib5" name="bbib5" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib5"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[5]</span></span></a>], further escalating the costs. To address these issues, researchers have increasingly turned their attention to Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs), which share similar charge-discharge mechanisms with LIBs. Both sodium (Na) and lithium (Li) belong to the alkali metal group in the periodic table, resulting in comparable physical and chemical properties. Moreover, sodium source is abundant, widely distributed, and easier to obtain, leading to lower costs for SIBs [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib6" name="bbib6" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib6"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">6</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib7" name="bbib7" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib7"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">7</span></span></a>]. However, the larger ionic radius of Na<sup>+</sup> (1.02&nbsp;Å compared to 0.76&nbsp;Å for Li<sup>+</sup>) and its higher relative atomic mass (23&nbsp;g&nbsp;mol&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> for Na vs. 6.9&nbsp;g&nbsp;mol&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> for Li) result in poorer kinetic performance and lower energy density for SIBs, hindering their widespread use in large-scale energy storage applications.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0045">Currently, a variety of cathode materials for SIBs are under extensive investigation, including layered transition metal oxides (Na<sub>x</sub>TMO<sub>2</sub>, 0&nbsp;＜&nbsp;x&nbsp;≤&nbsp;1, where TM denotes transition metal), polyanion compounds [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib8" name="bbib8" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib8"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">8</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib9" name="bbib9" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib9"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">9</span></span></a>], prussian blue analogs (PBAs) [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib10" name="bbib10" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib10"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">10</span></span></a>], and organic compounds [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib11" name="bbib11" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib11"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">11</span></span></a>]. Among these, layered oxides (Na<sub>x</sub>TMO<sub>2</sub>) has garnered significant attention due to the similarity in synthesis and structure of ion storage with Li-based ternary oxide cathodes. Compared to PBAs and polyanion compounds, layered oxides offer advantages such as facile synthesis, adjustable voltage range, high theoretical specific capacity, structural stability, and good sodium storage capacity ect [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib12" name="bbib12" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib12"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">12</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib13" name="bbib13" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib13"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">13</span></span></a>].</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0050">However, Na<sub>x</sub>TMO<sub>2</sub> cathodes face some challenges, including structural collapse, lower specific capacity, lower energy density, and reduced efficiency due to irreversible phase transitions [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib14" name="bbib14" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib14"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">14</span></span></a>] and transition metal (TM) dissolution during electrochemical cycling [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib15" name="bbib15" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib15"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[15]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib16" name="bbib16" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib16"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[16]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib17" name="bbib17" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib17"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[17]</span></span></a>]. Other issues include air instability [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib18" name="bbib18" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib18"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">18</span></span></a>], surface residual alkali [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib19" name="bbib19" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib19"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">19</span></span></a>], and slow kinetics caused by complex phase transitions ect. Recent research efforts have focused on modifying layered oxides to address these issues [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib14" name="bbib14" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib14"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">14</span></span></a>], such as (1) doping with specific elements to alter the charge density around Na<sup>+</sup> and strengthen TM-O bonds to stabilize the layered structure and inhibit phase transitions; (2) constructing intercrystalline symbiotic structures to leverage the benefits of different crystalline phases and enhance structural stability [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib13" name="bbib13" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib13"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">13</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib20" name="bbib20" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib20"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[20]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib21" name="bbib21" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib21"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[21]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib22" name="bbib22" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib22"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[22]</span></span></a>]; and (3) applying various coating materials, including oxide coating, phosphate coating [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib23" name="bbib23" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib23"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">23</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib24" name="bbib24" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib24"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">24</span></span></a>], and other coatings [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib25" name="bbib25" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib25"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">25</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib26" name="bbib26" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib26"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">26</span></span></a>], to create an inert separator layer or fast-ionic conductor that mitigates anisotropic volume changes and side reactions between the cathode and electrolyte. For example, Qi et al. [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib27" name="bbib27" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib27"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">27</span></span></a>] employed a ternary cathode gradient distribution strategy, coating MnO<sub>x</sub> on the surface of O3-NaNi<sub>1/3</sub>Fe<sub>1/3</sub>Mn<sub>1/3</sub>O<sub>2</sub> using a liquid-phase method to reduce residual alkali and improve electrochemical properties such as capacity retention and rate capacity. Similarly, Liu et al. [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib28" name="bbib28" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib28"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">28</span></span></a>] doped Ti and Mg as substitute elements for Co to obtain P2-Na<sub>0.67</sub>Mn<sub>0.53</sub>Ni<sub>0.30</sub>Mg<sub>0.085</sub>Ti<sub>0.085</sub>O<sub>2</sub>, thereby increasing the median discharge voltage from 3.21&nbsp;V to 3.59&nbsp;V and the energy density from 325&nbsp;Wh kg<sup>−1</sup> to 410&nbsp;Wh g<sup>−1</sup>, which can not only promote the O compensation reaction but also inhibit the O<sub>2</sub> loss at a high voltage of 4.25&nbsp;V. Li et al. [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib29" name="bbib29" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib29"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">29</span></span></a>] proposed constructing a NASICON-type NaTi<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> nanoshell to inhibit side reactions and Mn<sup>3+</sup> dissolution during cycling, thereby improving cycling stability and providing excellent Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion paths and higher electronic conductivity. Also, Professor Zhao's team [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib30" name="bbib30" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib30"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">30</span></span></a>] proposed the role of NaTi<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> as a coating layer of O3-NaNi<sub>1/3</sub>Fe<sub>1/3</sub>Mn<sub>1/3</sub>O<sub>2</sub>, the NaTi<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> coating layer can not only play a critical role in preventing the highly corrosive hydrofluoric acid (HF) attacks from decomposition of electrolyte and subsequent dissolution of the redox-active metal from the cathode particles but also expand the crystal spacing due to the partial doping of Ti<sup>4+</sup>, so as to stabilize the structure and promote the migration kinetics of Na<sup>+</sup>.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0055">Based on the arrangement of the TM layer and the coordination environment of Na<sup>+</sup>, layered oxide cathodes are usually classified into two categories: O3-type and P2-type. In P2 phase, Na<sup>+</sup> diffuses through adjacent prismatic sites with lower energy barriers, while in O3 phase, Na<sup>+</sup> must pass through a tetrahedral site with higher energy to move from one octahedral site to the next, resulting in poorer Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion kinetics and thus lower rate performance, which also impacts the cycling stability of the material. This phenomenon reflected in the design of pouch cell embodies high direct current resistance (DCR) and low energy efficiency, hindering large-scale application in energy storage systems. Previous studies have seldom focused specifically on the kinetic performance of materials, particularly in the field of layered oxides for SIBs. Rui et al. [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib31" name="bbib31" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib31"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">31</span></span></a>] proposed a superior LT SIB composed of 3D porous Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C (NVP/C-F) and NaTi<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C foams (NTP/C-F) to develop high-performance SIBs at low temperature. The designed 3D interconnected porous foam structures demonstrate excellent electrolyte absorption ability and Na<sup>+</sup> transport performance at low temperatures. Pang et al. [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib32" name="bbib32" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib32"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">32</span></span></a>] found that appropriate Al doping improved the electrochemical stability of layered Mn-based oxides, demonstrating better electrode kinetics (with better Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion coefficient). Kim et al. [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib33" name="bbib33" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib33"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">33</span></span></a>] proposed that the kinetic hindrance of cobalt-free cathode materials is significantly influenced by current rate and electrode loading level, leading to a reduction in reversible specific capacity and cycling performance. Additionally, particle size and residual lithium content also affect Li<sup>+</sup> diffusion kinetics. Thus, controlling particle size and employing strategies such as doping, coating, and washing to reduce residual lithium content are essential for enhancing the kinetic performance of materials.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0060">Based on prior research, we found that poor kinetic performance of materials not only affects capacity and cycling stability but also leads to increased DCR and reduced energy efficiency in pouch cells, thereby hindering the further development and application of SIBs in the energy-storage system. Therefore, we propose to enhance the kinetic performance of O3-type NaNi<sub>1/3</sub>Fe<sub>1/3</sub>Mn<sub>1/3</sub>O<sub>2</sub> layered oxides through topography control and component design (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig1" name="bfig1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>). On one hand, layered oxide cathodes typically exhibit a "flat sheet" morphology with crystals adhering to each other, this phenomenon adversely affects the kinetic performance of the material. To address the issue of improving the "flat sheet" morphology of layered oxides, we used Cu doping to reduce the exposure of inactive crystal plane (0 0 x) and promote de-flattening growth of crystals, thereby improving Na<sup>+</sup> transport pathways and enhancing the kinetic performance of the material. Additionally, the Cu<sup>2+</sup>/Cu<sup>3+</sup> redox electron pairs provide capacity compensation, slow down the phase transitions [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib34" name="bbib34" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib34"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">34</span></span></a>] during electrochemical processes, and enhance structural stability. On the other hand, considering that cathode inevitably undergoes side reactions at the interface with the electrolyte, leading to the formation of an inert CEI layer, and the presence of surface residue, which hinders Na<sup>+</sup> transport, we aim to suppress these interface side reactions by constructing an interface Na<sup>+</sup> fast-ion conductor layer to improve Na<sup>+</sup> transport kinetics. Therefore, we choose CoOOH coating strategy, where Na<sub>x</sub>CoO<sub>2</sub> (0 &lt; x&nbsp;≤&nbsp;1) forms with residual sodium on the material surface exhibits good ion diffusion rates and high redox potential, not only suppressing interface side reactions but also promoting Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion kinetics. The results show that although the two modification strategies we designed approach the problem from different angles, they ultimately both successfully improve the kinetic performance of O3-type NaNFMO. Verification results in pouch cells show that compared to NaNFMO, Cu-NaNFMO and NaNFMO@Co exhibit higher energy efficiency and better capacity retention under high current density conditions. This indicates that our modification strategies successfully improved the kinetic performance of O3-NaNFMO and provided new design ideas for the widespread and practical application of SIBs in the energy storage field.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig1"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324013582-gr1.jpg" height="222" alt="Fig. 1" aria-describedby="cap0010"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324013582-gr1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (276KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (276KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324013582-gr1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0010"><p id="fspara0010"><span class="label">Fig. 1</span>. Schematic diagram of the two modification strategies.</p></span></span></figure></div></section><section id="sec2"><h2 id="sectitle0035" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2. Materials and methods</h2><section id="sec2.1"><h3 id="sectitle0040" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.1. Material preparations</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0065">NaNi<sub>0.33</sub>Fe<sub>0.33</sub>Mn<sub>0.33</sub>O<sub>2</sub> (NaNFMO) and Cu-doping NaNi<sub>0.31</sub>Fe<sub>0.33</sub>Mn<sub>0.33</sub>Cu<sub>0.02</sub>O<sub>2</sub> (Cu-NaNFMO) were synthesized via solid-state reactions. The stoichiometric precursor Ni<sub>1/3</sub>Fe<sub>1/3</sub>Mn<sub>1/3</sub>(OH)<sub>2</sub>, anhydrous Na<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub> (with a 3&nbsp;% excess of Na), and nano CuO (Jinghuang Technology, 99.9&nbsp;%) were mixed in a ball mill at 200&nbsp;rpm for 5&nbsp;h. The mixture was then calcined in a tube furnace at 1050&nbsp;°C for 6&nbsp;h followed by 900&nbsp;°C for 12&nbsp;h. After naturally cooling to approximately 100&nbsp;°C, the materials were transferred to a glove box filled with argon (Ar) for grinding.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0070">The Co coating NaNi<sub>0.33</sub>Fe<sub>0.33</sub>Mn<sub>0.33</sub>O<sub>2</sub>@Co (NaNFMO@Co) was also synthesized via solid-state reactions. Appropriate amounts of NaNFMO and CoOOH (5000&nbsp;ppm, Yacheng New Energy) were mixed in a ball mill at 200&nbsp;rpm for 1.5&nbsp;h. The mixture was then transferred to a tube furnace and calcined in O<sub>2</sub> at 550&nbsp;°C for 4&nbsp;h. Upon cooling to 100&nbsp;°C, the material was quickly transferred to an Ar-filled glove box for grinding and storage.</div></section><section id="sec2.2"><h3 id="sectitle0045" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.2. Material characterizations</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0075">The actual chemical composition of the three samples was analyzed using inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES). The structure of the samples was examined using an X-ray diffractometer (XRD, Bruker D8 Discover). Field Emission Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM, S-4800, Hitachi Co., Japan), High Resolution Transmission Electron Microscopy (HRTEM, JEOL 2010F), and Energy Dispersive X-ray Spectroscopy (EDS) were employed to investigate particle morphology, size, and element distribution. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, PerkinElmer Co., USA) was utilized to determine the valence states of elements on the sample surfaces, with all peak positions corrected using the C 1s peak at 286.4&nbsp;eV.</div></section><section id="sec2.3"><h3 id="sectitle0050" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.3. Electrochemical measurements</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0080">CR2032 coin cells were assembled to test the electrochemical performance of the three samples. The active material, Super P, and PVDF were uniformly mixed at a mass ratio of 92:5:3 in an appropriate amount of N-methyl-2-pyrrolidinone (NMP) solvent to prepare a slurry. This slurry was evenly coated on aluminum foil and dried in a vacuum oven at 100&nbsp;°C for 12&nbsp;h. The dried cathode was cut into 12&nbsp;mm diameter discs (mass loading is about 5–6&nbsp;mg&nbsp;cm<sup>−2</sup>). The coin cells were then assembled in a glove box using 1&nbsp;M NaClO<sub>4</sub> in PC (100 VOL%) with a 5.0&nbsp;% FEC mixture as the electrolyte. Sodium metal served as the anode, and a glass fiber (Whatman GF/C 1822) was used as the separator. Charge-discharge tests were conducted at a constant current (1C&nbsp;=&nbsp;140&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>) on a battery test system (Land CT2001A, Wuhan Jinnuo Electronic Co., Ltd., China) between 2.0 and 4.0&nbsp;V at room temperature. Electrochemical Impedance Spectroscopy (EIS, 100&nbsp;kHz to 10&nbsp;mHz) and Cyclic Voltammetry (CV, 2.0–4.0&nbsp;V, Scan Rate&nbsp;=&nbsp;0.1&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup>) were performed on an electrochemical workstation (Biologic VSP-300). The Galvanostatic Intermittent Titration Technique (GITT, Biologic VSP-300) was used to evaluate the Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion coefficient (<span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-1-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>D</mi><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>N</mi><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>a</mi></mrow><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>+</mo></msup></msub></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="5.554ex" height="2.432ex" viewBox="0 -747.2 2391.1 1047.3" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.697ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-44"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(828,-239)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-4E"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(628,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-61"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1002,290)"><use transform="scale(0.5)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2B"></use></g></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">D</mi><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">N</mi><mi is="true">a</mi></mrow><mo is="true">+</mo></msup></msub></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-1"><math><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">D</mi><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">N</mi><mi is="true">a</mi></mrow><mo is="true">+</mo></msup></msub></mrow></math></script></span>), the current pulse was repeatedly applied at a current density of 0.1C for 10&nbsp;min, and then the open circuit was relaxed for 1&nbsp;h, and the above conditions were cycled until the voltage reached 4.0&nbsp;V. Similar to the charging process, in the discharging process, the Coin cells were cycled at 0.1&nbsp;C for an interval τ of 10&nbsp;min, and then the open circuit was relaxed for 1&nbsp;h, and the above conditions were cycled until the voltage reaches 2.0&nbsp;V.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0085">Assuming that the migration of Na<sup>+</sup> in the cathode material follows Fick's second law, and the molar volume remains constant during charge and discharge, the apparent chemical diffusion coefficient of Na<sup>+</sup> (<span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-44"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(828,-239)"><g is="true"><g x="3833" y="-1"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true"><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">m</mi><mi is="true">B</mi></msub><msub is="true"><mi is="true">V</mi><mi is="true">m</mi></msub></mrow><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi
