is="true">D</mi></mfrac></mrow><mo stretchy="true" is="true">)</mo></mrow></mrow></math></script></span></span></span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0090">In this formula, <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-4-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>m</mi><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>B</mi></msub></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="3.52ex" height="1.74ex" viewBox="0 -498.8 1515.5 749.2" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.582ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-6D"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(878,-150)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-42"></use></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">m</mi><mi is="true">B</mi></msub></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-4"><math><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">m</mi><mi is="true">B</mi></msub></mrow></math></script></span> is the mass of the active material, <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-5-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>V</mi><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>m</mi></msub></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="3.03ex" height="2.317ex" viewBox="0 -747.2 1304.7 997.6" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.582ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-56"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(583,-150)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-6D"></use></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">V</mi><mi is="true">m</mi></msub></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-5"><math><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">V</mi><mi is="true">m</mi></msub></mrow></math></script></span> is the molar volume, <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-6-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>M</mi><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>B</mi></msub></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="3.734ex" height="2.317ex" viewBox="0 -747.2 1607.5 997.6" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.582ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-4D"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(970,-150)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-42"></use></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">M</mi><mi is="true">B</mi></msub></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-6"><math><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">M</mi><mi is="true">B</mi></msub></mrow></math></script></span> is the molecular weight, S is the contact area between the electrode and the electrolyte, <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-7-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x394;</mo><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>E</mi></mrow><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>S</mi></msub></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="4.943ex" height="2.432ex" viewBox="0 -796.9 2128.4 1047.3" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.582ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-394"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(833,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-45"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1572,-155)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-53"></use></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">Δ</mo><mi is="true">E</mi></mrow><mi is="true">S</mi></msub></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-7"><math><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">Δ</mo><mi is="true">E</mi></mrow><mi is="true">S</mi></msub></mrow></math></script></span> and <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-8-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x394;</mo><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>E</mi></mrow><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x3C4;</mi></msub></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="4.733ex" height="2.432ex" viewBox="0 -796.9 2037.9 1047.3" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.582ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-394"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(833,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-45"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1572,-150)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-3C4"></use></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">Δ</mo><mi is="true">E</mi></mrow><mi is="true">τ</mi></msub></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-8"><math><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">Δ</mo><mi is="true">E</mi></mrow><mi is="true">τ</mi></msub></mrow></math></script></span> are respectively the steady-state voltage difference at rest and the total transient voltage difference after charging time τ, τ refers to the charging or discharging time.</div></section><section id="sec2.4"><h3 id="sectitle0055" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.4. Assembly and electrochemical test of pouch cell</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0095">Pouch cells were separately assembled using NaNFMO, Cu-NaNFMO, NaNFMO@Co cathodes, a hard carbon anode, and separator. The cathode slurry was coated onto Al foil in the ratio of 96&nbsp;wt% active material, 2.7&nbsp;wt% Super P, and 1.3&nbsp;wt% polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) in N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP). The hard carbon slurry was coated onto Al foil with 94.9&nbsp;wt% HC, 3.9&nbsp;wt% Super P, and 1.2&nbsp;wt% sodium carboxymethyl cellulose (CMC) in an aqueous solution. The CB content was 1.13, areal loading of the anode and cathode were 8.18&nbsp;mg&nbsp;cm<sup>2</sup> and 15.65&nbsp;mg&nbsp;cm<sup>2</sup>, respectively. The cathode-separator-anode assembles were prepared, and then stacked with 9 cathode electrodes by 10 anode electrodes and packaged in a plastic-laminated aluminum pouch. Resultant pouch cell was dried under vacuum at 80&nbsp;°C for 48&nbsp;h before being moved into a glove box for injecting electrolyte. The size of prepared pouch cells was 83&nbsp;×&nbsp;4&nbsp;×&nbsp;63&nbsp;mm&nbsp;(L&nbsp;×&nbsp;W&nbsp;×&nbsp;H). Prior to testing, the pouch cells were conditioned by pressing at 45&nbsp;°C, charging with a CCCV process to 3.95&nbsp;V at 0.1&nbsp;C, then discharging to 2&nbsp;V at 0.1&nbsp;C, followed by cycling tests at a current density of 0.5&nbsp;C.</div></section></section><section id="sec3"><h2 id="sectitle0060" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3. Results and discussion</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0100">The actual chemical compositions of NaNFMO, Cu-NaNFMO, and NaNFMO@Co were determined by ICP-AES, and the results are shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#tbl1" name="btbl1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="tbl1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table 1</span></span></a>, and the ratio of Ni/Fe/Mn/Cu was in line with the expected assumptions.</div><div class="tables frame-topbot colsep-0 rowsep-0" id="tbl1"><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0045"><p id="tspara0010"><span class="label">Table 1</span>. Stoichiometry measured by ICP-MS.</p></span></span><div class="groups"><table><thead><tr class="rowsep-1 valign-top"><td scope="col" rowspan="2"><span class="screen-reader-only">Empty Cell</span></td><th scope="col" colspan="4">Chemical composition (at%)</th></tr><tr class="rowsep-1 valign-top"><th scope="col">Ni</th><th scope="col">Fe</th><th scope="col">Mn</th><th scope="col">Cu</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr class="valign-top"><th class="align-left" scope="row">NaNFMO</th><td class="align-left"><strong>35.25</strong></td><td class="align-left"><strong>33.71</strong></td><td class="align-left"><strong>31.03</strong></td><td class="align-left"><strong>-</strong></td></tr><tr class="valign-top"><th class="align-left" scope="row">Cu-NaNFMO</th><td class="align-left"><strong>35.76</strong></td><td class="align-left"><strong>34.26</strong></td><td class="align-left"><strong>29.97</strong></td><td class="align-left"><strong>0.020</strong></td></tr><tr class="valign-top"><th class="align-left" scope="row">NaNFMO@Co</th><td class="align-left"><strong>35.30</strong></td><td class="align-left"><strong>33.35</strong></td><td class="align-left"><strong>29.40</strong></td><td class="align-left"><strong>-</strong></td></tr></tbody></table></div></div></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0105">The X-ray diffraction (XRD) results, shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig2" name="bfig2" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>a and b and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figs. S1a–b</span></span></a>, indicated that all three samples exhibited an O3-type structure corresponding to R <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-9-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mover accent=&quot;true&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>3</mn><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x203E;</mo></mover></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="1.325ex" height="2.202ex" viewBox="0 -846.5 570.5 947.9" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true" transform="translate(35,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-33"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(0,197)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-AF" x="-70" y="0"></use><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-AF" x="70" y="0"></use></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mover accent="true" is="true"><mn is="true">3</mn><mo is="true">‾</mo></mover></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-9"><math><mrow is="true"><mover accent="true" is="true"><mn is="true">3</mn><mo is="true">‾</mo></mover></mrow></math></script></span> m space group. The refinement parameters of the XRD results are provided in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table S1</span></span></a>. Compared with NaNFMO, the a-axis spacing, unit cell volume, and the lengths of the Na-O and Na-TM bonds in Cu-NaNFMO increased, while the c-axis spacing and the length of the TM-O bonds decreased, which were due to the fact that Cu<sup>2+</sup> substituted the TM<sup>n&nbsp;+</sup>&nbsp;site, and the Cu-O bond energy was greater than that of TM-O bond, so it was conducive to the (de)intercalation of Na<sup>+</sup> in the electrochemical redox process. NaNFMO@Co still retained the O3-type structure, with no significant shifts in peak positions, indicating that the Co coating did not alter the structure of the material.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig2"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324013582-gr2.jpg" height="747" alt="Fig. 2" aria-describedby="cap0015"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324013582-gr2_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (1MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (1MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324013582-gr2.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0015"><p id="fspara0015"><span class="label">Fig. 2</span>. Structural characterization. (a) XRD patterns of three samples; Rietveld refinement of XRD for (b) NaNFMO; (c) C 1s (d) O 1s XPS spectra of NaNFMO, Cu-NaNFMO, NaNFMO@Co.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0110">The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) results reveal the valence states of elements in the samples. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S2a</span></span></a> displays the XPS spectra for Ni 2p. The binding energy at 854.2 and 871.6&nbsp;eV correspond to Ni<sup>2+</sup>, [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib35" name="bbib35" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib35"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">35</span></span></a>] while those at 855.7 and 873.3&nbsp;eV correspond to Ni<sup>3+</sup>. Among the three samples, Cu-NaNFMO and NaNFMO@Co have lower Ni<sup>3+</sup> content and higher Ni<sup>2+</sup> content compared to NaNFMO. Based on charge balance, it is inferred that Cu-NaNFMO and NaNFMO@Co have higher Mn<sup>4+</sup> content than NaNFMO, which increases the bond energy of Mn-O and stabilizes the structure. Additionally, fewer Jahn-Teller active Ni<sup>3+</sup> reduce the likelihood of irreversible structural phase transitions [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib28" name="bbib28" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib28"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">28</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib29" name="bbib29" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib29"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">29</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib37" name="bbib37" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib37"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">37</span></span></a>]. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S2b</span></span></a> shows the XPS spectra for Fe 2p. The peak at 710.1&nbsp;eV corresponds to Fe<sup>2+</sup>, while those at 712.2&nbsp;eV and 724.3&nbsp;eV correspond to Fe<sup>3+</sup>, with a satellite peak at 718.3&nbsp;eV. The results indicate the coexistence of Fe<sup>2+</sup> and Fe<sup>3+</sup>, with Fe<sup>3+</sup> being the predominant oxidation state [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib28" name="bbib28" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib28"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">28</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib37" name="bbib37" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib37"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">37</span></span></a>]. The content of Fe<sup>3+</sup> in Cu-NaNFMO and NaNFMO@Co is higher than that in NaNFMO and the presence of Fe<sup>3+</sup> exhibits an electron-withdrawing state, which increases the oxidation state of surrounding Mn ions, thereby suppressing the Jahn-Teller effect induced by Mn<sup>3+</sup> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib38" name="bbib38" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib38"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">38</span></span></a>] and maintaining structural stability. Mn 2p spectra (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S2c</span></span></a>) shows the peaks at 641.6 and 653.3&nbsp;eV correspond to Mn<sup>3+</sup>, while those at 643.0 and 655.5&nbsp;eV correspond to Mn<sup>4+</sup>, and Mn<sup>4+</sup> is predominant [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib29" name="bbib29" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib29"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">29</span></span></a>]. Jahn-Teller distortion is primarily caused by Mn<sup>3+</sup>. Notably, compared to the original NaNFMO (48.35&nbsp;%), the Mn<sup>4+</sup> content in Cu-NaNFMO (56.19&nbsp;%) and NaNFMO@Co (57.69&nbsp;%) is increased while Mn<sup>3+</sup> content is decreased, which helps to suppress Jahn-Teller distortion, maintain the reversible storage performance of Na<sup>+</sup>, and enhance structural stability. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S3a</span></span></a> presents the XPS survey spectra for the three samples. The XPS spectra for Cu 2p in Cu-NaNFMO are shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S3b</span></span></a>. The Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2 peaks are located at 933.2 and 953.0&nbsp;eV, respectively, with a satellite peak at 945.0&nbsp;eV, indicating that Cu shows +2 state [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib37" name="bbib37" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib37"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">37</span></span></a>]. The XPS spectra for Co 2p in NaNFMO@Co are shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S3c</span></span></a>. Contrary to the general trend, the Co<sup>3+</sup> peaks are observed at lower binding energies of 779.6 and 794.4&nbsp;eV, while the Co<sup>2+</sup> peaks are at higher binding energies of 781.6 and 795.9&nbsp;eV, with a peak at 786.1&nbsp;eV corresponding to the satellite peak. This indicates successful coating of Co [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib42" name="bbib42" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib42"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[42]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib43" name="bbib43" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib43"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[43]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib44" name="bbib44" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib44"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[44]</span></span></a>]. Additionally, the O 1s spectrum (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig2" name="bfig2" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>d) reveals the peak at 528.8&nbsp;eV attributed to lattice oxygen, which corresponds to TM-O; the peak at 530.8&nbsp;eV assigned to oxygen species deposited on the material surface, such as Na<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub> and the peak at 535.5&nbsp;eV linked to oxygen in adsorbed water [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib35" name="bbib35" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib35"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[35]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib39" name="bbib39" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib39"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[39]</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib40" name="bbib40" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib40"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">40</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib45" name="bbib45" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib45"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">45</span></span></a>]. Analysis of the spectra indicates that the peaks related to adsorbed water in Cu-NaNFMO and NaNFMO@Co are smaller compared to those in NaNFMO, suggesting their better air stability. The C 1s spectrum (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig2" name="bfig2" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>c) exhibits peaks representing various carbon species: the peak at 284.3&nbsp;eV is attributed to C-C/C=O, and the peak at 289.1&nbsp;eV is associated with -C-C=O [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib36" name="bbib36" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib36"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[36]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib39" name="bbib39" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib39"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[39]</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib41" name="bbib41" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib41"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">41</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib46" name="bbib46" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib46"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[46]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib47" name="bbib47" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib47"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[47]</span></span></a>]. These analyses above indicate Cu doping and Co coating reduce residual alkali content.</div><section id="sec3.1"><h3 id="sectitle0065" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.1. Cu-doped layered oxide cathode</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0115">Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM) images (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3a–b, 3</span></span></a>d-e, and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figs. S4a–d</span></span></a>) revealed that Cu-NaNFMO had a more rounded morphology and uniform dispersion compared to the flattened morphology of pristine NaNFMO. EDS results (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>g and h) confirmed uniform distribution of Ni/Fe/Mn/Cu without significant enrichment. Transmission Electron Microscope (TEM) images (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>c and f) showed clear layered structures in both NaNFMO and Cu-NaNFMO, with the (1 0 2) crystal plane spacing increasing from 0.236&nbsp;nm to 0.249&nbsp;nm after Cu doping, consistent with the XRD results.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig3"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324013582-gr3.jpg" height="367" alt="Fig. 3" aria-describedby="cap0020"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324013582-gr3_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (2MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (2MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324013582-gr3.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0020"><p id="fspara0020"><span class="label">Fig. 3</span>. The SEM images of (a–b) NaNFMO and (d–e) Cu-NaNFMO; The HRTEM images and FFT (inset) patterns of (c) NaNFMO and (f) Cu-NaNFMO; The EDS mapping of (g) NaNFMO and (h) Cu-NaNFMO; Schematic diagram of (i) the optimized unit cells, (j) crystal planes and surface energies of NaNiO<sub>2</sub> and Cu-doped NaNiO<sub>2</sub>.</p></span></span></figure></div><section id="sec3.1.1"><h4 id="sectitle0070" class="u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.1.1. Effect of Cu doping on surface energy</h4><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0120">Due to the lower surface energy of the inactive crystal plane (0 0 x) than the active crystal plane (1 0 x), the inactive side (0 0 x) was always preferentially developed during the growth process, resulting in the crystals tend to grow flat and easily stick together. We utilized the Quantum Espresso (QE) software package to fine-tune the crystal structure and conduct energy calculations before and after Cu doping [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib48" name="bbib48" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib48"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">48</span></span></a>]. In this process, we employed the Perdew, Burke, and Ernzerhof (PBE) function under the Generalized Gradient Approximation (GGA) to handle exchange-related contributions [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib49" name="bbib49" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib49"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">49</span></span></a>]. The interaction between core and valence electrons was using optimized norm-conserving Vanderbilt (ONCV) pseudopotentials [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib50" name="bbib50" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib50"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">50</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib51" name="bbib51" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib51"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">51</span></span></a>]. To ensure accuracy, we set cutoffs for the wavefunctions and charge density at 120 Ry and 480 Ry, respectively. For the (0 0 3) crystal plane, we embarked on an initial structural optimization journey using a 9&nbsp;×&nbsp;9&nbsp;×&nbsp;1 Monkhorst-Pack k-point grid, relaxing until the force on every atom dwindled to less than 10<sup>−3</sup> Ry/Bohr. After this optimization, we introduced a 15&nbsp;Å vacuum layer on the (0 0 3) crystal plane and calculated. The surface energy (E) of this crystal plane was derived from the following equation:<span class="display"><span id="ufd2" class="formula"><span>E&nbsp;=&nbsp;E1 - N&nbsp;×&nbsp;E2</span></span></span>where E1 represents the energy of the unit cell, E2 symbolizes the energy of the slab, and N stands for the number of atoms in the slab. The treatment for the (1 0 4) crystal plane was essentially similar. VESTA is used for visualization processing [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib52" name="bbib52" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib52"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">52</span></span></a>].</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0125">The results showed that Cu doping increased the surface energy of the inactive (0 0 3) plane from 0.92&nbsp;J&nbsp;m<sup>−2</sup> to 1.36&nbsp;J&nbsp;m<sup>−2</sup>, and decreased the active (1 0 4) plane energy from 1.19&nbsp;J&nbsp;m<sup>−2</sup> to 0.89&nbsp;J&nbsp;m<sup>−2</sup> (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>i and j). This indicated inhibited growth of the (0 0 3) plane and promoted growth of the (1 0 4) plane, reducing mutual adhesion and enhancing crystal kinetics. These findings correspond to the SEM results showing improved crystal morphology with Cu doping.</div></section><section id="sec3.1.2"><h4 id="sectitle0075" class="u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.1.2. Improvement of electrochemical properties by Cu doping</h4><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0130">Electrochemical performance tests were conducted on assembled coin cells at a voltage of 2.0–4.0&nbsp;V. Cu-NaNFMO exhibited higher coulombic efficiency, better capacity retention after 100 cycles, and slower capacity decay compared to NaNFMO (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig4" name="bfig4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>a). The initial charge-discharge curves (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig4" name="bfig4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>b) indicated higher specific capacity and smoother curves for Cu-NaNFMO, attributable to the participation of Cu<sup>2+</sup>/Cu<sup>3+</sup> redox pairs providing additional capacity and mitigating irreversible phase transitions during redox processes. After experiencing a current density of 0.1&nbsp;C, 0.2&nbsp;C, 0.5&nbsp;C, 1&nbsp;C, 5&nbsp;C and then returning to 0.1&nbsp;C (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig4" name="bfig4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figs. 4</span></span></a>c and 1&nbsp;C&nbsp;=&nbsp;140&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>), Cu-NaNFMO could achieve a capacity recovery rate of 98.42&nbsp;%, while NaNFMO was only 96.77&nbsp;%, indicating that Cu-NaNFMO could maintain a higher capacity at a higher current density. Maintaining a scan rate of 0.1&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup>, Cyclic Voltammetry (CV) diagram (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig4" name="bfig4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>d and e) showed that the redox peak of Cu-NaNFMO at 3.15/2.85&nbsp;V was sharper and higher and the difference was smaller, indicating that Cu-NaNFMO had more storage energy capacity at low voltage and better reversibility during electrochemical cycling.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig4"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324013582-gr4.jpg" height="539" alt="Fig. 4" aria-describedby="cap0025"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324013582-gr4_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (836KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (836KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324013582-gr4.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0025"><p id="fspara0025"><span class="label">Fig. 4</span>. (a) Cycling performance, (b) the initial charge and discharge profiles, (c) rate capacity, (d–e) CV curves with 0.1&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup>, (f) curves of log <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-10-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>D</mi><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>N</mi><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>a</mi></mrow><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>+</mo></msup></msub></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="5.554ex" height="2.432ex" viewBox="0 -747.2 2391.1 1047.3" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.697ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-44"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(828,-239)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-4E"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(628,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-61"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1002,290)"><use transform="scale(0.5)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2B"></use></g></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">D</mi><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">N</mi><mi is="true">a</mi></mrow><mo is="true">+</mo></msup></msub></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-10"><math><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">D</mi><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">N</mi><mi is="true">a</mi></mrow><mo is="true">+</mo></msup></msub></mrow></math></script></span>-V with the voltage range of 2.0–4.0&nbsp;V of the NaNFMO and Cu-NaNFMO, EIS curves of (g) NaNFMO, (h) Cu-NaNFMO.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0135">The Electrochemical Impedance Spectroscopy (EIS) of NaNFMO and Cu-NaNFMO were shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig4" name="bfig4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>g–h, and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S5</span></span></a> shows the equivalent circuit. The semicircle at high-frequency represented the membrane impedance (R<sub>f</sub>), and the semicircle at low-frequency represented the charge transfer impedance (R<sub>ct</sub>), both were increased with the cycles, but the impedance of Cu-NaNFMO was much smaller than that of NaNFMO. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S6a</span></span></a> shows a schematic illustration of the single-step GITT process. In this context, Ohmic polarization refers to the voltage difference between the initial charging voltage and the previous relaxation voltage during the relaxation process. Voltage polarization is defined as the difference between the charging termination voltage and the equilibrium voltage at the end of the next relaxation process. The magnitudes of Voltage polarization and Ohmic polarization directly reflect the rate of Na<sup>+</sup> deintercalation. Comparing the GITT results, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figs. S6b and S6c</span></span></a>, the Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion coefficients (<span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-11-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>D</mi><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>N</mi><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>a</mi></mrow><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>+</mo></msup></msub></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="5.554ex" height="2.432ex" viewBox="0 -747.2 2391.1 1047.3" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.697ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-44"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(828,-239)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-4E"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(628,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-61"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1002,290)"><use transform="scale(0.5)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2B"></use></g></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">D</mi><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">N</mi><mi is="true">a</mi></mrow><mo is="true">+</mo></msup></msub></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-11"><math><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">D</mi><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">N</mi><mi is="true">a</mi></mrow><mo is="true">+</mo></msup></msub></mrow></math></script></span>) for NaNFMO and Cu-NaNFMO both fall within the magnitude range of 10<sup>−11</sup> to 10<sup>−9</sup>&nbsp;cm<sup>2</sup>&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup>. Notably, Cu-NaNFMO exhibits a higher DNa⁺ (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig4" name="bfig4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>f), indicating better kinetic performance.</div></section></section><section id="sec3.2"><h3 id="sectitle0080" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.2. CoOOH coating layered oxide cathode</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0140">SEM results (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig5" name="bfig5" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig5"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>a and b and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figs. S4e–f</span></span></a>) indicated that the morphology of NaNFMO did not significantly change after Co coating, although the edges and corners were slightly passivated. TEM images (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig5" name="bfig5" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig5"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>c) showed that the coating layer was relatively homogeneous, with a thickness of about 4–6&nbsp;nm. EDS results (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig5" name="bfig5" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig5"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>d) confirmed an even distribution of Ni, Fe, Mn, and Co elements, indicating a uniform Co coating.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig5"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324013582-gr5.jpg" height="411" alt="Fig. 5" aria-describedby="cap0030"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324013582-gr5_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (2MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (2MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324013582-gr5.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0030"><p id="fspara0030"><span class="label">Fig. 5</span>. The SEM (a–b), HRTEM image and FFT (inset) pattern (c) and EDS image (d) of NaNFMO@Co.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0145">Effects of Co coating on the electrochemical properties. The initial cycle charge-discharge curves for NaNFMO and NaNFMO@Co (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig6" name="bfig6" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig6"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>a) demonstrated that NaNFMO@Co exhibited a higher specific capacity and a smoother electrochemical curve. This improvement could be attributed to high-temperature calcination under O<sub>2</sub>, which compensates for structural damage and oxygen loss, partially recovering capacity. Additionally, NaNFMO@Co showed reduced polarization, indicating decreased residual alkali. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig6" name="bfig6" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig6"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>b shows that NaNFMO@Co had a capacity retention rate of 66.19&nbsp;% after 100 cycles, significantly higher than 58.13&nbsp;% of the NaNFMO. At the same time, the first cycle coulombic efficiency (CE) of NaNFMO@Co also improved from 90.69&nbsp;% to 93.57&nbsp;%, enhancing the energy efficiency of the material.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig6"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324013582-gr6.jpg" height="304" alt="Fig. 6" aria-describedby="cap0035"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324013582-gr6_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (587KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (587KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324013582-gr6.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0035"><p id="fspara0035"><span class="label">Fig. 6</span>. (a) The initial charge and discharge profiles, (b) cycling performance, (c) rate capacity, (d) CV curves with 0.1&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup> and (e) GITT curves of NaNFMO@Co, (f) curves of log <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-12-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>D</mi><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="5.554ex" height="2.432ex" viewBox="0 -747.2 2391.1 1047.3" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.697ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-44"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(828,-239)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-4E"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(628,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-61"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1002,290)"><use transform="scale(0.5)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2B"></use></g></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">D</mi><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">N</mi><mi is="true">a</mi></mrow><mo is="true">+</mo></msup></msub></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-12"><math><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">D</mi><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">N</mi><mi is="true">a</mi></mrow><mo is="true">+</mo></msup></msub></mrow></math></script></span>-V with the voltage range of 2.0–4.0&nbsp;V of the NaNFMO and NaNFMO@Co, (g) EIS curves.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0150">Rate performance data (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig6" name="bfig6" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig6"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>c) revealed that NaNFMO@Co achieved a 97.56&nbsp;% capacity recovery after cycling at a high current of 5&nbsp;C and returning to a low current of 0.1&nbsp;C (1&nbsp;C&nbsp;=&nbsp;140&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>), indicating smoother Na<sup>+</sup> deintercalation and improved kinetics after Co coating. The overall resistance of the NaNFMO@Co cathode was lower than that of NaNFMO (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig4" name="bfig4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig6" name="bfig6" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig6"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>g). The CV curves (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig6" name="bfig6" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig6"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>d) compared the redox behavior of NaNFMO and NaNFMO@Co at a scan rate of 0.1&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup>, with the redox peak at 3.15/2.85&nbsp;V representing the Ni<sup>2+</sup>/Ni<sup>3+</sup> redox pair [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib53" name="bbib53" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib53"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">53</span></span></a>]. The peaks of NaNFMO@Co were sharper, higher, and had a smaller gap, indicating better electrochemical reversibility. GITT results (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig6" name="bfig6" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig6"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>e and f) showed that NaNFMO@Co maintained <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-13-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>D</mi><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>N</mi><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>a</mi></mrow><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>+</mo></msup></msub></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="5.554ex" height="2.432ex" viewBox="0 -747.2 2391.1 1047.3" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.697ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-44"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(828,-239)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-4E"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(628,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-61"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1002,290)"><use transform="scale(0.5)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2B"></use></g></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">D</mi><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">N</mi><mi is="true">a</mi></mrow><mo is="true">+</mo></msup></msub></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-13"><math><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">D</mi><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">N</mi><mi is="true">a</mi></mrow><mo is="true">+</mo></msup></msub></mrow></math></script></span> in the order of 10<sup>−11</sup> to 10<sup>−9</sup>, reflecting superior kinetic performance.</div></section><section id="sec3.3"><h3 id="sectitle0085" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.3. Residual alkali</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0155">Residual alkali is a significant issue for SIBs cathodes. Surface residual sodium reacts with H<sub>2</sub>O and CO<sub>2</sub> in the air, forming NaOH and Na<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib54" name="bbib54" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib54"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">54</span></span></a>], while lattice sodium can be exchanged by protons H, leading to lattice destruction and structural collapse. Surface residual sodium further reacts with the electrolyte, evolving gas during electrochemical cycles and increasing battery safety risks. These residues also form surface resistance compounds, hindering Na<sup>+</sup> deintercalation and degrading electrochemical performance. Additionally, the strong alkalinity of residual sodium can cause defluoridation of the PVDF binder in the slurry, leading to gelation and flocculation during slurry coating [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib55" name="bbib55" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib55"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">55</span></span></a>]. Residual alkali content results (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S7a</span></span></a>) showed that Cu doping improved air stability of the sample and reduced structural Na&nbsp;<sup>+</sup>&nbsp;substitution by H<sub>2</sub>O, thus lowering residual alkali. NaNFMO@Co exhibited a significant reduction in residual alkali, likely due to the reaction between Co and residual Na<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub> forming Na<sub>x</sub>CoO<sub>2</sub>, which consumes residual alkali. Na<sub>x</sub>CoO<sub>2</sub> also serves as an excellent Na&nbsp;<sup>+</sup>&nbsp;transport medium, improving the kinetics of Na<sup>+</sup>. XRD analysis (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S7b</span></span></a>) confirmed the formation of Na<sub>0.6</sub>CoO<sub>2</sub> from calcining an equal molar mixture of Na<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub> and CoOOH at 550&nbsp;°C for 4&nbsp;h in O<sub>2</sub>, proving that CoOOH reacts with surface residual alkali after Co coating, reducing polarization and enhancing kinetics of the material.</div></section><section id="sec3.4"><h3 id="sectitle0090" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.4. Pouch cells data validation</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0160">Pouch cells were assembled using NaNFMO, Cu-NaNFMO, and NaNFMO@Co cathods, and their cycling curves were shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig7" name="bfig7" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig7"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>a. During 500 cycles, Cu-NaNFMO and NaNFMO@Co demonstrated greater stability, with capacity retention rates of 97.98&nbsp;% and 99.22&nbsp;%, respectively, higher than that of NaNFMO (94.71&nbsp;%). The initial charge-discharge curves (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig7" name="bfig7" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig7"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>b) revealed that Cu-NaNFMO and NaNFMO@Co had initial capacities of 1290 mAh and 1289 mAh, respectively, higher than that of NaNFMO (1286 mAh), and the first two had a higher voltage plateau. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig7" name="bfig7" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig7"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>c shows that NaNFMO@Co exhibited the best rate performance, followed by Cu-NaNFMO, and NaNFMO last. Furthermore, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig7" name="bfig7" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig7"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>d indicates that the energy efficiency of Cu-NaNFMO and NNFMO@Co is 94&nbsp;% and 95.7&nbsp;% at 0.5&nbsp;C respectively, which is greater than that of NaNFMO (93.3&nbsp;%). This phenomenon suggests that, under equivalent discharge conditions, Cu-NaNFMO and NaNFMO@Co utilize energy more effectively, contributing to reduced electricity costs and enhanced energy efficiency. Additionally, NaNFMO@Co had a DCR of 51.3&nbsp;mΩ, significantly lower than that of NaNFMO (63.3&nbsp;mΩ), validating the effectiveness of Co coating in enhancing material kinetics. The DCR of Cu-NaNFMO was 66.61&nbsp;mΩ, higher than NaNFMO's 63.3&nbsp;mΩ, which is attributed to the larger single crystal size due to Cu doping, slightly raising the DCR but overall improving energy efficiency. In summary, Cu doping and Co coating strategies significantly enhanced the performance metrics of the pouch cells, demonstrating the feasibility of our modification strategy.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig7"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324013582-gr7.jpg" height="452" alt="Fig. 7" aria-describedby="cap0040"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324013582-gr7_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (600KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (600KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324013582-gr7.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0040"><p id="fspara0040"><span class="label">Fig. 7</span>. (a) Cycling performance; (b) The initial charge and discharge profiles; (c) Rate capacity, (d) DCR and energy efficiency in 0.5C of the pouch cells of NaNFMO, Cu-NaNFMO and NaNFMO@Co.</p></span></span></figure></div></section></section><section id="sec4"><h2 id="sectitle0095" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">4. Conclusion</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0165">O3-NaNFMO was synthesized via a solid-state reaction, and the O3-type Cu-NaNFMO and NaNFMO@Co were successfully obtained through Cu doping and Co coating strategies. Cu doping improved the "flat sheet" morphology of the layered oxide, formed strong Cu-O bonds, stabilized the layered structure, and expanded the diffusion paths of Na<sup>+</sup>. The Co coating reacted with residual sodium on the surface to produce the Na<sup>+</sup> fast ionic conductor Na<sub>x</sub>CoO<sub>2</sub>, thereby promoting the migration of Na<sup>+</sup>. Both strategies significantly enhanced the kinetic performance of pristine NaNFMO. Additionally, the energy efficiency of pouch cells made from Cu-NaNFMO and NaNFMO@Co was markedly improved.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0170">As discussed above, the capacity of NaNFMO was increased by approximately 4–5 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>, the capacity retention after 100 cycles was improved by about 10&nbsp;%, and electrochemical reversibility was significantly enhanced. Furthermore, Cu doping and Co coating effectively inhibited the anisotropic volume changes of pristine NaNFMO during charging and discharging process, thereby stabilizing the structure.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0175">In summary, our work has significantly improved the kinetics and electrochemical performance of layered oxides, providing a feasible method for the practical application and promotion of layered oxides in SIBs.</div></section><section id="sec6"><h2 id="sectitle0105" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">CRediT authorship contribution statement</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0185"><strong>Xue Wen:</strong> Writing – original draft, Methodology, Investigation, Formal analysis, Data curation, Conceptualization. <strong>Haoyang Yuan:</strong> Methodology, Investigation. <strong>Yite Liu:</strong> Investigation. <strong>Tao Huang:</strong> Writing – review &amp; editing, Visualization, Resources, Methodology. <strong>Aishui Yu:</strong> Writing – review &amp; editing, Visualization, Resources, Project administration, Funding acquisition.</div></section></div><section id="coi0010"><h2 id="sectitle0110" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Declaration of competing interest</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0190">The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.</div></section><section id="ack0010"><h2 id="sectitle0115" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Acknowledgements</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0195">We gratefully acknowledge the financial support from the <span id="gs1">Science and Technology Commission of Shanghai Municipality</span> of China (Grant No. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gs1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">19DZ2270100</span></span></a>).</div></section><div class="Appendices"><section id="appsec1"><h2 id="sectitle0120" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Appendix B.     const pendoData = {"visitor":{"pageName":"SD:product:journal:article","pageType":"CP-CA","pageProduct":"SD","pageLanguage":"en","pageEnvironment":"prod","accessType":"ae:ANON_IP","countryCode":"GB"},"account":{"id":"ae:11279","name":"ae:Imperial College London"},"events":{}};;
    pendoData.events = {
      ready: function () {
        pendo.addAltText();
      },
    };
    function runPendo(data, options) {
  const {
    firstDelay,
    maxRetries,
    urlPrefix,
    urlSuffix,
    apiKey
  } = options;
  (function (apiKey) {
    (function (p, e, n, d, o) {
      var v, w, x, y, z;
      o = p[d] = p[d] || {};
      o._q = [];
      v = ['initialize', 'identify', 'updateOptions', 'pageLoad'];
      for (w = 0, x = v.length; w < x; ++w) (function (m) {
        o[m] = o[m] || function () {
          o._q[m === v[0] ? 'unshift' : 'push']([m].concat([].slice.call(arguments, 0)));
        };
      })(v[w]);
      y = e.createElement(n);
      y.async = !0;
      y.src = urlPrefix + apiKey + urlSuffix;
      z = e.getElementsByTagName(n)[0];
      z.parentNode.insertBefore(y, z);
    })(window, document, 'script', 'pendo');
    pendo.addAltText = function () {
      var target = document.querySelector('body');
      var observer = new MutationObserver(function (mutations) {
        mutations.forEach(function (mutation) {
          if (mutation?.addedNodes?.length) {
            if (mutation.addedNodes[0]?.className?.includes("_pendo-badge")) {
              const badge = mutation.addedNodes[0];
              const altText = badge?.attributes['aria-label']?.value || 'Feedback';
              const pendoBadgeImage = pendo.dom(`#${badge?.attributes?.id.value} img`);
              if (pendoBadgeImage.length) {
                pendoBadgeImage[0]?.setAttribute('alt', altText);
              }
            }
          }
        });
      });
      var config = {
        attributeFilter: ['data-layout'],
        attributes: true,
        childList: true,
        characterData: true,
        subtree: false
      };
      observer.observe(target, config);
    };
  })(apiKey);
  (function watchAndSetPendo(nextDelay, retryAttempt) {
    if (data.visitor.id) {
      console.debug(`initializing pendo`);
      pendo.initialize(data);
    } else if (typeof pageDataTracker === 'object' && typeof pageDataTracker.getVisitorId === 'function' && pageDataTracker.getVisitorId()) {
      data.visitor.id = pageDataTracker.getVisitorId();
      console.debug(`initializing pendo`);
      pendo.initialize(data);
    } else {
      if (retryAttempt > 0) {
        return setTimeout(function () {
          watchAndSetPendo(nextDelay * 2, retryAttempt - 1);
        }, nextDelay);
      }
      pendo.initialize(data);
      console.debug(`gave up ... pendo initialized`);
    }
  })(firstDelay, maxRetries);
}
    window.addPendoScript = () => {
      runPendo(pendoData, {
        firstDelay: 100,
        maxRetries: 5,
        urlPrefix: 'https://cdn.pendo.io/agent/static/',
        urlSuffix: '/pendo.js',
        apiKey: 'd6c1d995-bc7e-4e53-77f1-2ea4ecbb9565',
      });
      window.addPendoScript = () => {};
    };
    addEventListener('load', () => window.addPendoScript());
  </script>
