class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Cite</span></span></button></div></div></div></div></div><div class="ArticleIdentifierLinks u-margin-xs-bottom text-xs" id="article-identifier-links"><a class="anchor doi anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jpowsour.2024.235406" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener" aria-label="Persistent link using digital object identifier" title="Persistent link using digital object identifier"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jpowsour.2024.235406</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a><a class="anchor rights-and-content anchor-primary" href="https://s100.copyright.com/AppDispatchServlet?publisherName=ELS&amp;contentID=S0378775324013582&amp;orderBeanReset=true" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Get rights and content</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></div><div class="LicenseInfo text-xs u-margin-xs-bottom access-type-label-only"><div class="AccessLabel"><span class="access-indicator"></span>Full text access</div></div><section class="ReferencedArticles"></section><section class="ReferencedArticles"></section><div class="PageDivider"></div><div class="Abstracts u-font-serif" id="abstracts"><div class="abstract author-highlights" id="abs0015" lang="en"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Highlights</h2><div id="abssec0015"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="abspara0015"><ul class="list"><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0010">A kinetic study of O3-NaNFMO by Cu doping and Co coating is introduced.</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0015">Effects of Cu doping have been evaluated.</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0020">Mechanism of and Co coating have been studied.</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0025">Improvement of DCR and Energy Efficiency of pouch cells have been evaluated.</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0030">Surface residual alkali of the material is evaluated.</div></span></li></ul></div></div></div><div class="abstract author" id="abs0010" lang="en"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Abstract</h2><div id="abssec0010"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="abspara0010">Layered transition metal oxides (Na<sub>x</sub>TMO<sub>2</sub>, 0 &lt; x&nbsp;≤&nbsp;1) are considered one of the most promising cathodes for Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) due to their high theoretical capacity and operability. However, Na<sub>x</sub>TMO<sub>2</sub> still faces significant challenges, including poor kinetic performance and low energy efficiency. Herein, in order to enhance the kinetics of NaNi<sub>1/3</sub>Fe<sub>1/3</sub>Mn<sub>1/3</sub>O<sub>2</sub> (NaNFMO), topography control and component design were proposed: First, Cu doping (Cu-NaNFMO) was used to expand lattice channels and improve “flat sheet” of layered oxide, which synergistically enhanced transport kinetics of Na<sup>+</sup>. Second, Co coating (NaNFMO@Co) reacted with surface residue to form a fast-ionic conductor Na<sub>x</sub>CoO<sub>2</sub> (0 &lt; x&nbsp;≤&nbsp;1), which inhibited interfacial side reactions and enhanced transport kinetics of Na<sup>+</sup>. Furthermore, the presence of strong Cu-O bonds in Cu-NaNFMO and fast-ionic conductor Na<sub>x</sub>CoO<sub>2</sub> in NaNFMO@Co led to better electrochemical redox performance, the initial charge specific capacity of NaNFMO was increased from 141.5 mAh g⁻<sup>1</sup> to 145.8 mAh g⁻<sup>1</sup> and 144 mAh g⁻<sup>1</sup>, with capacity retention improving by nearly 10&nbsp;% after 100 cycles. Furthermore, NaNFMO@Co improves ICE from 90.56&nbsp;% to 93.57&nbsp;%. With the improved kinetics, the DCR of pouch cells decreased, and the energy efficiency increased from 93.3&nbsp;% to 94&nbsp;% and 95.7&nbsp;%.</div></div></div></div><ul id="issue-navigation" class="issue-navigation u-margin-s-bottom u-bg-grey1"><li class="previous move-left u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-left"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-left" href="/science/article/pii/S0378775324013648"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-left"><path d="M1 61l45-45 7 7-38 38 38 38-7 7z"></path></svg><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Previous <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span></a></li><li class="next move-right u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-right"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-right" href="/science/article/pii/S0378775324013466"><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Next <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-right"><path d="M1 99l38-38L1 23l7-7 45 45-45 45z"></path></svg></a></li></ul><div class="Keywords u-font-serif"><div id="kwrds0010" class="keywords-section"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Keywords</h2><div id="kwrd0010" class="keyword"><span>Sodium-ion battery</span></div><div id="kwrd0015" class="keyword"><span>Cu doping</span></div><div id="kwrd0020" class="keyword"><span>Co coating</span></div><div id="kwrd0025" class="keyword"><span>Improved kinetics</span></div><div id="kwrd0030" class="keyword"><span>Pouch cell</span></div></div></div><div class="Body u-font-serif" id="body"><div><section id="sec1"><h2 id="sectitle0030" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">1. Introduction</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0040">In recent years, the continuous development of energy storage and electric vehicles has led to widespread use of Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) due to their high specific capacity, long cycling performance, and high energy density [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib1" name="bbib1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">1</span></span></a>]. However, the high cost of LIBs is a significant drawback, primarily due to the scarcity and uneven distribution of lithium resources in nature. Additionally, the recycling of lithium sources from spent batteries is challenging and inefficient [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib2" name="bbib2" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[2]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib3" name="bbib3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[3]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib4" name="bbib4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[4]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib5" name="bbib5" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib5"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[5]</span></span></a>], further escalating the costs. To address these issues, researchers have increasingly turned their attention to Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs), which share similar charge-discharge mechanisms with LIBs. Both sodium (Na) and lithium (Li) belong to the alkali metal group in the periodic table, resulting in comparable physical and chemical properties. Moreover, sodium source is abundant, widely distributed, and easier to obtain, leading to lower costs for SIBs [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib6" name="bbib6" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib6"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">6</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib7" name="bbib7" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib7"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">7</span></span></a>]. However, the larger ionic radius of Na<sup>+</sup> (1.02&nbsp;Å compared to 0.76&nbsp;Å for Li<sup>+</sup>) and its higher relative atomic mass (23&nbsp;g&nbsp;mol&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> for Na vs. 6.9&nbsp;g&nbsp;mol&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> for Li) result in poorer kinetic performance and lower energy density for SIBs, hindering their widespread use in large-scale energy storage applications.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0045">Currently, a variety of cathode materials for SIBs are under extensive investigation, including layered transition metal oxides (Na<sub>x</sub>TMO<sub>2</sub>, 0&nbsp;＜&nbsp;x&nbsp;≤&nbsp;1, where TM denotes transition metal), polyanion compounds [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib8" name="bbib8" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib8"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">8</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib9" name="bbib9" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib9"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">9</span></span></a>], prussian blue analogs (PBAs) [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib10" name="bbib10" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib10"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">10</span></span></a>], and organic compounds [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib11" name="bbib11" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib11"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">11</span></span></a>]. Among these, layered oxides (Na<sub>x</sub>TMO<sub>2</sub>) has garnered significant attention due to the similarity in synthesis and structure of ion storage with Li-based ternary oxide cathodes. Compared to PBAs and polyanion compounds, layered oxides offer advantages such as facile synthesis, adjustable voltage range, high theoretical specific capacity, structural stability, and good sodium storage capacity ect [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib12" name="bbib12" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib12"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">12</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib13" name="bbib13" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib13"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">13</span></span></a>].</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0050">However, Na<sub>x</sub>TMO<sub>2</sub> cathodes face some challenges, including structural collapse, lower specific capacity, lower energy density, and reduced efficiency due to irreversible phase transitions [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib14" name="bbib14" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib14"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">14</span></span></a>] and transition metal (TM) dissolution during electrochemical cycling [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib15" name="bbib15" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib15"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[15]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib16" name="bbib16" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib16"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[16]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib17" name="bbib17" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib17"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[17]</span></span></a>]. Other issues include air instability [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib18" name="bbib18" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib18"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">18</span></span></a>], surface residual alkali [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib19" name="bbib19" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib19"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">19</span></span></a>], and slow kinetics caused by complex phase transitions ect. Recent research efforts have focused on modifying layered oxides to address these issues [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib14" name="bbib14" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib14"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">14</span></span></a>], such as (1) doping with specific elements to alter the charge density around Na<sup>+</sup> and strengthen TM-O bonds to stabilize the layered structure and inhibit phase transitions; (2) constructing intercrystalline symbiotic structures to leverage the benefits of different crystalline phases and enhance structural stability [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib13" name="bbib13" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib13"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">13</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib20" name="bbib20" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib20"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[20]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib21" name="bbib21" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib21"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[21]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib22" name="bbib22" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib22"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[22]</span></span></a>]; and (3) applying various coating materials, including oxide coating, phosphate coating [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib23" name="bbib23" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib23"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">23</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib24" name="bbib24" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib24"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">24</span></span></a>], and other coatings [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib25" name="bbib25" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib25"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">25</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib26" name="bbib26" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib26"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">26</span></span></a>], to create an inert separator layer or fast-ionic conductor that mitigates anisotropic volume changes and side reactions between the cathode and electrolyte. For example, Qi et al. [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib27" name="bbib27" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib27"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">27</span></span></a>] employed a ternary cathode gradient distribution strategy, coating MnO<sub>x</sub> on the surface of O3-NaNi<sub>1/3</sub>Fe<sub>1/3</sub>Mn<sub>1/3</sub>O<sub>2</sub> using a liquid-phase method to reduce residual alkali and improve electrochemical properties such as capacity retention and rate capacity. Similarly, Liu et al. [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib28" name="bbib28" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib28"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">28</span></span></a>] doped Ti and Mg as substitute elements for Co to obtain P2-Na<sub>0.67</sub>Mn<sub>0.53</sub>Ni<sub>0.30</sub>Mg<sub>0.085</sub>Ti<sub>0.085</sub>O<sub>2</sub>, thereby increasing the median discharge voltage from 3.21&nbsp;V to 3.59&nbsp;V and the energy density from 325&nbsp;Wh kg<sup>−1</sup> to 410&nbsp;Wh g<sup>−1</sup>, which can not only promote the O compensation reaction but also inhibit the O<sub>2</sub> loss at a high voltage of 4.25&nbsp;V. Li et al. [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib29" name="bbib29" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib29"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">29</span></span></a>] proposed constructing a NASICON-type NaTi<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> nanoshell to inhibit side reactions and Mn<sup>3+</sup> dissolution during cycling, thereby improving cycling stability and providing excellent Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion paths and higher electronic conductivity. Also, Professor Zhao's team [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib30" name="bbib30" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib30"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">30</span></span></a>] proposed the role of NaTi<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> as a coating layer of O3-NaNi<sub>1/3</sub>Fe<sub>1/3</sub>Mn<sub>1/3</sub>O<sub>2</sub>, the NaTi<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> coating layer can not only play a critical role in preventing the highly corrosive hydrofluoric acid (HF) attacks from decomposition of electrolyte and subsequent dissolution of the redox-active metal from the cathode particles but also expand the crystal spacing due to the partial doping of Ti<sup>4+</sup>, so as to stabilize the structure and promote the migration kinetics of Na<sup>+</sup>.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0055">Based on the arrangement of the TM layer and the coordination environment of Na<sup>+</sup>, layered oxide cathodes are usually classified into two categories: O3-type and P2-type. In P2 phase, Na<sup>+</sup> diffuses through adjacent prismatic sites with lower energy barriers, while in O3 phase, Na<sup>+</sup> must pass through a tetrahedral site with higher energy to move from one octahedral site to the next, resulting in poorer Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion kinetics and thus lower rate performance, which also impacts the cycling stability of the material. This phenomenon reflected in the design of pouch cell embodies high direct current resistance (DCR) and low energy efficiency, hindering large-scale application in energy storage systems. Previous studies have seldom focused specifically on the kinetic performance of materials, particularly in the field of layered oxides for SIBs. Rui et al. [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib31" name="bbib31" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib31"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">31</span></span></a>] proposed a superior LT SIB composed of 3D porous Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C (NVP/C-F) and NaTi<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub>/C foams (NTP/C-F) to develop high-performance SIBs at low temperature. The designed 3D interconnected porous foam structures demonstrate excellent electrolyte absorption ability and Na<sup>+</sup> transport performance at low temperatures. Pang et al. [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib32" name="bbib32" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib32"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">32</span></span></a>] found that appropriate Al doping improved the electrochemical stability of layered Mn-based oxides, demonstrating better electrode kinetics (with better Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion coefficient). Kim et al. [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib33" name="bbib33" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib33"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">33</span></span></a>] proposed that the kinetic hindrance of cobalt-free cathode materials is significantly influenced by current rate and electrode loading level, leading to a reduction in reversible specific capacity and cycling performance. Additionally, particle size and residual lithium content also affect Li<sup>+</sup> diffusion kinetics. Thus, controlling particle size and employing strategies such as doping, coating, and washing to reduce residual lithium content are essential for enhancing the kinetic performance of materials.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0060">Based on prior research, we found that poor kinetic performance of materials not only affects capacity and cycling stability but also leads to increased DCR and reduced energy efficiency in pouch cells, thereby hindering the further development and application of SIBs in the energy-storage system. Therefore, we propose to enhance the kinetic performance of O3-type NaNi<sub>1/3</sub>Fe<sub>1/3</sub>Mn<sub>1/3</sub>O<sub>2</sub> layered oxides through topography control and component design (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig1" name="bfig1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>). On one hand, layered oxide cathodes typically exhibit a "flat sheet" morphology with crystals adhering to each other, this phenomenon adversely affects the kinetic performance of the material. To address the issue of improving the "flat sheet" morphology of layered oxides, we used Cu doping to reduce the exposure of inactive crystal plane (0 0 x) and promote de-flattening growth of crystals, thereby improving Na<sup>+</sup> transport pathways and enhancing the kinetic performance of the material. Additionally, the Cu<sup>2+</sup>/Cu<sup>3+</sup> redox electron pairs provide capacity compensation, slow down the phase transitions [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib34" name="bbib34" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib34"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">34</span></span></a>] during electrochemical processes, and enhance structural stability. On the other hand, considering that cathode inevitably undergoes side reactions at the interface with the electrolyte, leading to the formation of an inert CEI layer, and the presence of surface residue, which hinders Na<sup>+</sup> transport, we aim to suppress these interface side reactions by constructing an interface Na<sup>+</sup> fast-ion conductor layer to improve Na<sup>+</sup> transport kinetics. Therefore, we choose CoOOH coating strategy, where Na<sub>x</sub>CoO<sub>2</sub> (0 &lt; x&nbsp;≤&nbsp;1) forms with residual sodium on the material surface exhibits good ion diffusion rates and high redox potential, not only suppressing interface side reactions but also promoting Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion kinetics. The results show that although the two modification strategies we designed approach the problem from different angles, they ultimately both successfully improve the kinetic performance of O3-type NaNFMO. Verification results in pouch cells show that compared to NaNFMO, Cu-NaNFMO and NaNFMO@Co exhibit higher energy efficiency and better capacity retention under high current density conditions. This indicates that our modification strategies successfully improved the kinetic performance of O3-NaNFMO and provided new design ideas for the widespread and practical application of SIBs in the energy storage field.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig1"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324013582-gr1.jpg" height="222" alt="Fig. 1" aria-describedby="cap0010"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324013582-gr1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (276KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (276KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324013582-gr1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0010"><p id="fspara0010"><span class="label">Fig. 1</span>. Schematic diagram of the two modification strategies.</p></span></span></figure></div></section><section id="sec2"><h2 id="sectitle0035" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2. Materials and methods</h2><section id="sec2.1"><h3 id="sectitle0040" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.1. Material preparations</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0065">NaNi<sub>0.33</sub>Fe<sub>0.33</sub>Mn<sub>0.33</sub>O<sub>2</sub> (NaNFMO) and Cu-doping NaNi<sub>0.31</sub>Fe<sub>0.33</sub>Mn<sub>0.33</sub>Cu<sub>0.02</sub>O<sub>2</sub> (Cu-NaNFMO) were synthesized via solid-state reactions. The stoichiometric precursor Ni<sub>1/3</sub>Fe<sub>1/3</sub>Mn<sub>1/3</sub>(OH)<sub>2</sub>, anhydrous Na<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub> (with a 3&nbsp;% excess of Na), and nano CuO (Jinghuang Technology, 99.9&nbsp;%) were mixed in a ball mill at 200&nbsp;rpm for 5&nbsp;h. The mixture was then calcined in a tube furnace at 1050&nbsp;°C for 6&nbsp;h followed by 900&nbsp;°C for 12&nbsp;h. After naturally cooling to approximately 100&nbsp;°C, the materials were transferred to a glove box filled with argon (Ar) for grinding.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0070">The Co coating NaNi<sub>0.33</sub>Fe<sub>0.33</sub>Mn<sub>0.33</sub>O<sub>2</sub>@Co (NaNFMO@Co) was also synthesized via solid-state reactions. Appropriate amounts of NaNFMO and CoOOH (5000&nbsp;ppm, Yacheng New Energy) were mixed in a ball mill at 200&nbsp;rpm for 1.5&nbsp;h. The mixture was then transferred to a tube furnace and calcined in O<sub>2</sub> at 550&nbsp;°C for 4&nbsp;h. Upon cooling to 100&nbsp;°C, the material was quickly transferred to an Ar-filled glove box for grinding and storage.</div></section><section id="sec2.2"><h3 id="sectitle0045" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.2. Material characterizations</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0075">The actual chemical composition of the three samples was analyzed using inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES). The structure of the samples was examined using an X-ray diffractometer (XRD, Bruker D8 Discover). Field Emission Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM, S-4800, Hitachi Co., Japan), High Resolution Transmission Electron Microscopy (HRTEM, JEOL 2010F), and Energy Dispersive X-ray Spectroscopy (EDS) were employed to investigate particle morphology, size, and element distribution. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, PerkinElmer Co., USA) was utilized to determine the valence states of elements on the sample surfaces, with all peak positions corrected using the C 1s peak at 286.4&nbsp;eV.</div></section><section id="sec2.3"><h3 id="sectitle0050" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.3. Electrochemical measurements</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0080">CR2032 coin cells were assembled to test the electrochemical performance of the three samples. The active material, Super P, and PVDF were uniformly mixed at a mass ratio of 92:5:3 in an appropriate amount of N-methyl-2-pyrrolidinone (NMP) solvent to prepare a slurry. This slurry was evenly coated on aluminum foil and dried in a vacuum oven at 100&nbsp;°C for 12&nbsp;h. The dried cathode was cut into 12&nbsp;mm diameter discs (mass loading is about 5–6&nbsp;mg&nbsp;cm<sup>−2</sup>). The coin cells were then assembled in a glove box using 1&nbsp;M NaClO<sub>4</sub> in PC (100 VOL%) with a 5.0&nbsp;% FEC mixture as the electrolyte. Sodium metal served as the anode, and a glass fiber (Whatman GF/C 1822) was used as the separator. Charge-discharge tests were conducted at a constant current (1C&nbsp;=&nbsp;140&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>) on a battery test system (Land CT2001A, Wuhan Jinnuo Electronic Co., Ltd., China) between 2.0 and 4.0&nbsp;V at room temperature. Electrochemical Impedance Spectroscopy (EIS, 100&nbsp;kHz to 10&nbsp;mHz) and Cyclic Voltammetry (CV, 2.0–4.0&nbsp;V, Scan Rate&nbsp;=&nbsp;0.1&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup>) were performed on an electrochemical workstation (Biologic VSP-300). The Galvanostatic Intermittent Titration Technique (GITT, Biologic VSP-300) was used to evaluate the Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion coefficient (<span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-1-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>D</mi><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>N</mi><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>a</mi></mrow><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>+</mo></msup></msub></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="5.554ex" height="2.432ex" viewBox="0 -747.2 2391.1 1047.3" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.697ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-44"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(828,-239)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-4E"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(628,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-61"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1002,290)"><use transform="scale(0.5)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2B"></use></g></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">D</mi><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">N</mi><mi is="true">a</mi></mrow><mo is="true">+</mo></msup></msub></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-1"><math><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">D</mi><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">N</mi><mi is="true">a</mi></mrow><mo is="true">+</mo></msup></msub></mrow></math></script></span>), the current pulse was repeatedly applied at a current density of 0.1C for 10&nbsp;min, and then the open circuit was relaxed for 1&nbsp;h, and the above conditions were cycled until the voltage reached 4.0&nbsp;V. Similar to the charging process, in the discharging process, the Coin cells were cycled at 0.1&nbsp;C for an interval τ of 10&nbsp;min, and then the open circuit was relaxed for 1&nbsp;h, and the above conditions were cycled until the voltage reaches 2.0&nbsp;V.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0085">Assuming that the migration of Na<sup>+</sup> in the cathode material follows Fick's second law, and the molar volume remains constant during charge and discharge, the apparent chemical diffusion coefficient of Na<sup>+</sup> (<span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-2-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>D</mi><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>N</mi><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>a</mi></mrow><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>+</mo></msup></msub></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" is="true">B</mi></msub></mrow></math></script></span> is the molecular weight, S is the contact area between the electrode and the electrolyte, <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-7-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x394;</mo><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>E</mi></mrow><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>S</mi></msub></mrow></math>" role="presentation" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.582ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-394"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(833,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-45"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1572,-155)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-53"></use></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow id="MathJax-Element-7"><math><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">Δ</mo><mi is="true">E</mi></mrow><mi is="true">S</mi></msub></mrow></math></script></span> and <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-8-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x394;</mo><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>E</mi></mrow><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x3C4;</mi></msub></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="4.733ex" height="2.432ex" viewBox="0 -796.9 2037.9 1047.3" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.582ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-394"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(833,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-45"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1572,-150)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-3C4"></use></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">Δ</mo><mi is="true">E</mi></mrow><mi is="true">τ</mi></msub></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-8"><math><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">Δ</mo><mi is="true">E</mi></mrow><mi is="true">τ</mi></msub></mrow></math></script></span> are respectively the steady-state voltage difference at rest and the total transient voltage difference after charging time τ, τ refers to the charging or discharging time.</div></section><section id="sec2.4"><h3 id="sectitle0055" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.4. Assembly and electrochemical test of pouch cell</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0095">Pouch cells were separately assembled using NaNFMO, Cu-NaNFMO, NaNFMO@Co cathodes, a hard carbon anode, and separator. The cathode slurry was coated onto Al foil in the ratio of 96&nbsp;wt% active material, 2.7&nbsp;wt% Super P, and 1.3&nbsp;wt% polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) in N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP). The hard carbon slurry was coated onto Al foil with 94.9&nbsp;wt% HC, 3.9&nbsp;wt% Super P, and 1.2&nbsp;wt% sodium carboxymethyl cellulose (CMC) in an aqueous solution. The CB content was 1.13, areal loading of the anode and cathode were 8.18&nbsp;mg&nbsp;cm<sup>2</sup> and 15.65&nbsp;mg&nbsp;cm<sup>2</sup>, respectively. The cathode-separator-anode assembles were prepared, and then stacked with 9 cathode electrodes by 10 anode electrodes and packaged in a plastic-laminated aluminum pouch. Resultant pouch cell was dried under vacuum at 80&nbsp;°C for 48&nbsp;h before being moved into a glove box for injecting electrolyte. The size of prepared pouch cells was 83&nbsp;×&nbsp;4&nbsp;×&nbsp;63&nbsp;mm&nbsp;(L&nbsp;×&nbsp;W&nbsp;×&nbsp;H). Prior to testing, the pouch cells were conditioned by pressing at 45&nbsp;°C, charging with a CCCV process to 3.95&nbsp;V at 0.1&nbsp;C, then discharging to 2&nbsp;V at 0.1&nbsp;C, followed by cycling tests at a current density of 0.5&nbsp;C.</div></section></section><section id="sec3"><h2 id="sectitle0060" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3. Results and discussion</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0100">The actual chemical compositions of NaNFMO, Cu-NaNFMO, and NaNFMO@Co were determined by ICP-AES, and the results are shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#tbl1" name="btbl1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="tbl1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table 1</span></span></a>, and the ratio of Ni/Fe/Mn/Cu was in line with the expected assumptions.</div><div class="tables frame-topbot colsep-0 rowsep-0" id="tbl1"><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0045"><p id="tspara0010"><span class="label">Table 1</span>. Stoichiometry measured by ICP-MS.</p></span></span><div class="groups"><table><thead><tr class="rowsep-1 valign-top"><td scope="col" rowspan="2"><span class="screen-reader-only">Empty Cell</span></td><th scope="col" colspan="4">Chemical composition (at%)</th></tr><tr class="rowsep-1 valign-top"><th scope="col">Ni</th><th scope="col">Fe</th><th scope="col">Mn</th><th scope="col">Cu</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr class="valign-top"><th class="align-left" scope="row">NaNFMO</th><td class="align-left"><strong>35.25</strong></td><td class="align-left"><strong>33.71</strong></td><td class="align-left"><strong>31.03</strong></td><td class="align-left"><strong>-</strong></td></tr><tr class="valign-top"><th class="align-left" scope="row">Cu-NaNFMO</th><td class="align-left"><strong>35.76</strong></td><td class="align-left"><strong>34.26</strong></td><td class="align-left"><strong>29.97</strong></td><td class="align-left"><strong>0.020</strong></td></tr><tr class="valign-top"><th class="align-left" scope="row">NaNFMO@Co</th><td class="align-left"><strong>35.30</strong></td><td class="align-left"><strong>33.35</strong></td><td class="align-left"><strong>29.40</strong></td><td class="align-left"><strong>-</strong></td></tr></tbody></table></div></div></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0105">The X-ray diffraction (XRD) results, shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig2" name="bfig2" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>a and b and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figs. S1a–b</span></span></a>, indicated that all three samples exhibited an O3-type structure corresponding to R <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-9-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mover accent=&quot;true&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>3</mn><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x203E;</mo></mover></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="1.325ex" height="2.202ex" viewBox="0 -846.5 570.5 947.9" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true" transform="translate(35,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-33"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(0,197)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-AF" x="-70" y="0"></use><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-AF" x="70" y="0"></use></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mover accent="true" is="true"><mn is="true">3</mn><mo is="true">‾</mo></mover></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-9"><math><mrow is="true"><mover accent="true" is="true"><mn is="true">3</mn><mo is="true">‾</mo></mover></mrow></math></script></span> m space group. The refinement parameters of the XRD results are provided in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table S1</span></span></a>. Compared with NaNFMO, the a-axis spacing, unit cell volume, and the lengths of the Na-O and Na-TM bonds in Cu-NaNFMO increased, while the c-axis spacing and the length of the TM-O bonds decreased, which were due to the fact that Cu<sup>2+</sup> substituted the TM<sup>n&nbsp;+</sup>&nbsp;site, and the Cu-O bond energy was greater than that of TM-O bond, so it was conducive to the (de)intercalation of Na<sup>+</sup> in the electrochemical redox process. NaNFMO@Co still retained the O3-type structure, with no significant shifts in peak positions, indicating that the Co coating did not alter the structure of the material.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig2"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324013582-gr2.jpg" height="747" alt="Fig. 2" aria-describedby="cap0015"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324013582-gr2_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (1MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (1MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324013582-gr2.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0015"><p id="fspara0015"><span class="label">Fig. 2</span>. Structural characterization. (a) XRD patterns of three samples; Rietveld refinement of XRD for (b) NaNFMO; (c) C 1s (d) O 1s XPS spectra of NaNFMO, Cu-NaNFMO, NaNFMO@Co.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0110">The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) results reveal the valence states of elements in the samples. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S2a</span></span></a> displays the XPS spectra for Ni 2p. The binding energy at 854.2 and 871.6&nbsp;eV correspond to Ni<sup>2+</sup>, [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib35" name="bbib35" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib35"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">35</span></span></a>] while those at 855.7 and 873.3&nbsp;eV correspond to Ni<sup>3+</sup>. Among the three samples, Cu-NaNFMO and NaNFMO@Co have lower Ni<sup>3+</sup> content and higher Ni<sup>2+</sup> content compared to NaNFMO. Based on charge balance, it is inferred that Cu-NaNFMO and NaNFMO@Co have higher Mn<sup>4+</sup> content than NaNFMO, which increases the bond energy of Mn-O and stabilizes the structure. Additionally, fewer Jahn-Teller active Ni<sup>3+</sup> reduce the likelihood of irreversible structural phase transitions [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib28" name="bbib28" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib28"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">28</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib29" name="bbib29" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib29"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">29</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib37" name="bbib37" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib37"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">37</span></span></a>]. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S2b</span></span></a> shows the XPS spectra for Fe 2p. The peak at 710.1&nbsp;eV corresponds to Fe<sup>2+</sup>, while those at 712.2&nbsp;eV and 724.3&nbsp;eV correspond to Fe<sup>3+</sup>, with a satellite peak at 718.3&nbsp;eV. The results indicate the coexistence of Fe<sup>2+</sup> and Fe<sup>3+</sup>, with Fe<sup>3+</sup> being the predominant oxidation state [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib28" name="bbib28" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib28"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">28</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib37" name="bbib37" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib37"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">37</span></span></a>]. The content of Fe<sup>3+</sup> in Cu-NaNFMO and NaNFMO@Co is higher than that in NaNFMO and the presence of Fe<sup>3+</sup> exhibits an electron-withdrawing state, which increases the oxidation state of surrounding Mn ions, thereby suppressing the Jahn-Teller effect induced by Mn<sup>3+</sup> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib38" name="bbib38" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib38"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">38</span></span></a>] and maintaining structural stability. Mn 2p spectra (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S2c</span></span></a>) shows the peaks at 641.6 and 653.3&nbsp;eV correspond to Mn<sup>3+</sup>, while those at 643.0 and 655.5&nbsp;eV correspond to Mn<sup>4+</sup>, and Mn<sup>4+</sup> is predominant [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib29" name="bbib29" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib29"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">29</span></span></a>]. Jahn-Teller distortion is primarily caused by Mn<sup>3+</sup>. Notably, compared to the original NaNFMO (48.35&nbsp;%), the Mn<sup>4+</sup> content in Cu-NaNFMO (56.19&nbsp;%) and NaNFMO@Co (57.69&nbsp;%) is increased while Mn<sup>3+</sup> content is decreased, which helps to suppress Jahn-Teller distortion, maintain the reversible storage performance of Na<sup>+</sup>, and enhance structural stability. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S3a</span></span></a> presents the XPS survey spectra for the three samples. The XPS spectra for Cu 2p in Cu-NaNFMO are shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S3b</span></span></a>. The Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2 peaks are located at 933.2 and 953.0&nbsp;eV, respectively, with a satellite peak at 945.0&nbsp;eV, indicating that Cu shows +2 state [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib37" name="bbib37" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib37"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">37</span></span></a>]. The XPS spectra for Co 2p in NaNFMO@Co are shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S3c</span></span></a>. Contrary to the general trend, the Co<sup>3+</sup> peaks are observed at lower binding energies of 779.6 and 794.4&nbsp;eV, while the Co<sup>2+</sup> peaks are at higher binding energies of 781.6 and 795.9&nbsp;eV, with a peak at 786.1&nbsp;eV corresponding to the satellite peak. This indicates successful coating of Co [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib42" name="bbib42" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib42"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[42]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib43" name="bbib43" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib43"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[43]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib44" name="bbib44" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib44"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[44]</span></span></a>]. Additionally, the O 1s spectrum (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig2" name="bfig2" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>d) reveals the peak at 528.8&nbsp;eV attributed to lattice oxygen, which corresponds to TM-O; the peak at 530.8&nbsp;eV assigned to oxygen species deposited on the material surface, such as Na<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub> and the peak at 535.5&nbsp;eV linked to oxygen in adsorbed water [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib35" name="bbib35" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib35"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[35]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib39" name="bbib39" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib39"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[39]</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib40" name="bbib40" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib40"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">40</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib45" name="bbib45" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib45"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">45</span></span></a>]. Analysis of the spectra indicates that the peaks related to adsorbed water in Cu-NaNFMO and NaNFMO@Co are smaller compared to those in NaNFMO, suggesting their better air stability. The C 1s spectrum (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig2" name="bfig2" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>c) exhibits peaks representing various carbon species: the peak at 284.3&nbsp;eV is attributed to C-C/C=O, and the peak at 289.1&nbsp;eV is associated with -C-C=O [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib36" name="bbib36" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib36"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[36]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib39" name="bbib39" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib39"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[39]</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib41" name="bbib41" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib41"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">41</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib46" name="bbib46" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib46"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[46]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib47" name="bbib47" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib47"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[47]</span></span></a>]. These analyses above indicate Cu doping and Co coating reduce residual alkali content.</div><section id="sec3.1"><h3 id="sectitle0065" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.1. Cu-doped layered oxide cathode</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0115">Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM) images (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3a–b, 3</span></span></a>d-e, and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figs. S4a–d</span></span></a>) revealed that Cu-NaNFMO had a more rounded morphology and uniform dispersion compared to the flattened morphology of pristine NaNFMO. EDS results (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>g and h) confirmed uniform distribution of Ni/Fe/Mn/Cu without significant enrichment. Transmission Electron Microscope (TEM) images (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>c and f) showed clear layered structures in both NaNFMO and Cu-NaNFMO, with the (1 0 2) crystal plane spacing increasing from 0.236&nbsp;nm to 0.249&nbsp;nm after Cu doping, consistent with the XRD results.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig3"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324013582-gr3.jpg" height="367" alt="Fig. 3" aria-describedby="cap0020"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324013582-gr3_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (2MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (2MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324013582-gr3.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0020"><p id="fspara0020"><span class="label">Fig. 3</span>. The SEM images of (a–b) NaNFMO and (d–e) Cu-NaNFMO; The HRTEM images and FFT (inset) patterns of (c) NaNFMO and (f) Cu-NaNFMO; The EDS mapping of (g) NaNFMO and (h) Cu-NaNFMO; Schematic diagram of (i) the optimized unit cells, (j) crystal planes and surface energies of NaNiO<sub>2</sub> and Cu-doped NaNiO<sub>2</sub>.</p></span></span></figure></div><section id="sec3.1.1"><h4 id="sectitle0070" class="u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.1.1. Effect of Cu doping on surface energy</h4><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0120">Due to the lower surface energy of the inactive crystal plane (0 0 x) than the active crystal plane (1 0 x), the inactive side (0 0 x) was always preferentially developed during the growth process, resulting in the crystals tend to grow flat and easily stick together. We utilized the Quantum Espresso (QE) software package to fine-tune the crystal structure and conduct energy calculations before and after Cu doping [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib48" name="bbib48" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib48"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">48</span></span></a>]. In this process, we employed the Perdew, Burke, and Ernzerhof (PBE) function under the Generalized Gradient Approximation (GGA) to handle exchange-related contributions [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib49" name="bbib49" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib49"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">49</span></span></a>]. The interaction between core and valence electrons was using optimized norm-conserving Vanderbilt (ONCV) pseudopotentials [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib50" name="bbib50" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib50"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">50</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib51" name="bbib51" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib51"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">51</span></span></a>]. To ensure accuracy, we set cutoffs for the wavefunctions and charge density at 120 Ry and 480 Ry, respectively. For the (0 0 3) crystal plane, we embarked on an initial structural optimization journey using a 9&nbsp;×&nbsp;9&nbsp;×&nbsp;1 Monkhorst-Pack k-point grid, relaxing until the force on every atom dwindled to less than 10<sup>−3</sup> Ry/Bohr. After this optimization, we introduced a 15&nbsp;Å vacuum layer on the (0 0 3) crystal plane and calculated. The surface energy (E) of this crystal plane was derived from the following equation:<span class="display"><span id="ufd2" class="formula"><span>E&nbsp;=&nbsp;E1 - N&nbsp;×&nbsp;E2</span></span></span>where E1 represents the energy of the unit cell, E2 symbolizes the energy of the slab, and N stands for the number of atoms in the slab. The treatment for the (1 0 4) crystal plane was essentially similar. VESTA is used for visualization processing [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib52" name="bbib52" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib52"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">52</span></span></a>].</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0125">The results showed that Cu doping increased the surface energy of the inactive (0 0 3) plane from 0.92&nbsp;J&nbsp;m<sup>−2</sup> to 1.36&nbsp;J&nbsp;m<sup>−2</sup>, and decreased the active (1 0 4) plane energy from 1.19&nbsp;J&nbsp;m<sup>−2</sup> to 0.89&nbsp;J&nbsp;m<sup>−2</sup> (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>i and j). This indicated inhibited growth of the (0 0 3) plane and promoted growth of the (1 0 4) plane, reducing mutual adhesion and enhancing crystal kinetics. These findings correspond to the SEM results showing improved crystal morphology with Cu doping.</div></section><section id="sec3.1.2"><h4 id="sectitle0075" class="u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.1.2. Improvement of electrochemical properties by Cu doping</h4><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0130">Electrochemical performance tests were conducted on assembled coin cells at a voltage of 2.0–4.0&nbsp;V. Cu-NaNFMO exhibited higher coulombic efficiency, better capacity retention after 100 cycles, and slower capacity decay compared to NaNFMO (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig4" name="bfig4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>a). The initial charge-discharge curves (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig4" name="bfig4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>b) indicated higher specific capacity and smoother curves for Cu-NaNFMO, attributable to the participation of Cu<sup>2+</sup>/Cu<sup>3+</sup> redox pairs providing additional capacity and mitigating irreversible phase transitions during redox processes. After experiencing a current density of 0.1&nbsp;C, 0.2&nbsp;C, 0.5&nbsp;C, 1&nbsp;C, 5&nbsp;C and then returning to 0.1&nbsp;C (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig4" name="bfig4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figs. 4</span></span></a>c and 1&nbsp;C&nbsp;=&nbsp;140&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>), Cu-NaNFMO could achieve a capacity recovery rate of 98.42&nbsp;%, while NaNFMO was only 96.77&nbsp;%, indicating that Cu-NaNFMO could maintain a higher capacity at a higher current density. Maintaining a scan rate of 0.1&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup>, Cyclic Voltammetry (CV) diagram (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig4" name="bfig4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>d and e) showed that the redox peak of Cu-NaNFMO at 3.15/2.85&nbsp;V was sharper and higher and the difference was smaller, indicating that Cu-NaNFMO had more storage energy capacity at low voltage and better reversibility during electrochemical cycling.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig4"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324013582-gr4.jpg" height="539" alt="Fig. 4" aria-describedby="cap0025"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324013582-gr4_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (836KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (836KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324013582-gr4.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0025"><p id="fspara0025"><span class="label">Fig. 4</span>. (a) Cycling performance, (b) the initial charge and discharge profiles, (c) rate capacity, (d–e) CV curves with 0.1&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup>, (f) curves of log <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-10-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>D</mi><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>N</mi><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>a</mi></mrow><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>+</mo></msup></msub></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="5.554ex" height="2.432ex" viewBox="0 -747.2 2391.1 1047.3" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.697ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-44"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(828,-239)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-4E"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(628,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-61"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1002,290)"><use transform="scale(0.5)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2B"></use></g></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">D</mi><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">N</mi><mi is="true">a</mi></mrow><mo is="true">+</mo></msup></msub></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-10"><math><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">D</mi><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">N</mi><mi is="true">a</mi></mrow><mo is="true">+</mo></msup></msub></mrow></math></script></span>-V with the voltage range of 2.0–4.0&nbsp;V of the NaNFMO and Cu-NaNFMO, EIS curves of (g) NaNFMO, (h) Cu-NaNFMO.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0135">The Electrochemical Impedance Spectroscopy (EIS) of NaNFMO and Cu-NaNFMO were shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig4" name="bfig4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>g–h, and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S5</span></span></a> shows the equivalent circuit. The semicircle at high-frequency represented the membrane impedance (R<sub>f</sub>), and the semicircle at low-frequency represented the charge transfer impedance (R<sub>ct</sub>), both were increased with the cycles, but the impedance of Cu-NaNFMO was much smaller than that of NaNFMO. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S6a</span></span></a> shows a schematic illustration of the single-step GITT process. In this context, Ohmic polarization refers to the voltage difference between the initial charging voltage and the previous relaxation voltage during the relaxation process. Voltage polarization is defined as the difference between the charging termination voltage and the equilibrium voltage at the end of the next relaxation process. The magnitudes of Voltage polarization and Ohmic polarization directly reflect the rate of Na<sup>+</sup> deintercalation. Comparing the GITT results, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figs. S6b and S6c</span></span></a>, the Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion coefficients (<span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-11-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>D</mi><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>N</mi><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>a</mi></mrow><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>+</mo></msup></msub></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="5.554ex" height="2.432ex" viewBox="0 -747.2 2391.1 1047.3" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.697ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-44"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(828,-239)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-4E"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(628,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-61"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1002,290)"><use transform="scale(0.5)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2B"></use></g></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">D</mi><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">N</mi><mi is="true">a</mi></mrow><mo is="true">+</mo></msup></msub></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-11"><math><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">D</mi><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">N</mi><mi is="true">a</mi></mrow><mo is="true">+</mo></msup></msub></mrow></math></script></span>) for NaNFMO and Cu-NaNFMO both fall within the magnitude range of 10<sup>−11</sup> to 10<sup>−9</sup>&nbsp;cm<sup>2</sup>&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup>. Notably, Cu-NaNFMO exhibits a higher DNa⁺ (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig4" name="bfig4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>f), indicating better kinetic performance.</div></section></section><section id="sec3.2"><h3 id="sectitle0080" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.2. CoOOH coating layered oxide cathode</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0140">SEM results (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig5" name="bfig5" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig5"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>a and b and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figs. S4e–f</span></span></a>) indicated that the morphology of NaNFMO did not significantly change after Co coating, although the edges and corners were slightly passivated. TEM images (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig5" name="bfig5" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig5"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>c) showed that the coating layer was relatively homogeneous, with a thickness of about 4–6&nbsp;nm. EDS results (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig5" name="bfig5" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig5"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>d) confirmed an even distribution of Ni, Fe, Mn, and Co elements, indicating a uniform Co coating.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig5"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324013582-gr5.jpg" height="411" alt="Fig. 5" aria-describedby="cap0030"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324013582-gr5_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (2MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (2MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324013582-gr5.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0030"><p id="fspara0030"><span class="label">Fig. 5</span>. The SEM (a–b), HRTEM image and FFT (inset) pattern (c) and EDS image (d) of NaNFMO@Co.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0145">Effects of Co coating on the electrochemical properties. The initial cycle charge-discharge curves for NaNFMO and NaNFMO@Co (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig6" name="bfig6" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig6"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>a) demonstrated that NaNFMO@Co exhibited a higher specific capacity and a smoother electrochemical curve. This improvement could be attributed to high-temperature calcination under O<sub>2</sub>, which compensates for structural damage and oxygen loss, partially recovering capacity. Additionally, NaNFMO@Co showed reduced polarization, indicating decreased residual alkali. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig6" name="bfig6" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig6"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>b shows that NaNFMO@Co had a capacity retention rate of 66.19&nbsp;% after 100 cycles, significantly higher than 58.13&nbsp;% of the NaNFMO. At the same time, the first cycle coulombic efficiency (CE) of NaNFMO@Co also improved from 90.69&nbsp;% to 93.57&nbsp;%, enhancing the energy efficiency of the material.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig6"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324013582-gr6.jpg" height="304" alt="Fig. 6" aria-describedby="cap0035"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324013582-gr6_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (587KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (587KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775324013582-gr6.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0035"><p id="fspara0035"><span class="label">Fig. 6</span>. (a) The initial charge and discharge profiles, (b) cycling performance, (c) rate capacity, (d) CV curves with 0.1&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup> and (e) GITT curves of NaNFMO@Co, (f) curves of log <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-12-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>D</mi><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi transform="translate(828,-239)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-4E"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(628,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)"
